The tickling was making Maddie go wild and she thrashed as much as she could in her position, her eyes screwed up and I could even see tears trickling down her face. I filed away the fact Maddie had a ticklish butt away for a later date, would prove fun to exploit at some point. I tried to focus on the matter at hand and a steady growth in my loins reminded me of my nudity just as Maddie's begging reached a new height "AHHAASOOMMEEBODEEHEHEEPPLEEASEHEHEHEELLPPAAAHAHAA!!!" She screamed through her laughter, thrusting her hips forward with each swipe the feathers made against her buns but unable to ever escape.

"Shall I strip her of her remaining clothes before we free her?" Qumsal asked, making me jump as I had been enjoying the sight before me so much I'd forgotten she was standing there "Although the statue hasn't shown all of its abilities yet. We could leave her there and witness it if you so wish."

I had to admit, that idea has a very high appeal to it although leaving Maddie like that seemed far too cruel. Pondering for only a few moments, I decided too...
114211122122111221211.title: Not the only one...

choices: I resigned for a minute, it really wasn't that bad...
Yeah, the return of an invading goddess was pretty urgent.
1142111221221112212111.content:
"How do we turn off the trap?" I asked. Sure, watching Maddie in this position was fun, but I agreed to help her stop T'Calu, and it would just be too cruel to make her suffer even more than she already was.

Looking somewhat disappointed, Qumsal answered. "These traps were designed to capture intruders, not detain them. Each of them has an easy way of disabling and resetting the trap." She pointed at the other statue, opposite the one where Maddie hung laughing and screaming. "Push my foot on that statue, and that should free your companion. It won't restore her clothes however."

Walking over to the stone duplication of the sorceress, I couldn't help but marvel at how remarkable the craftsmanship was. The original and the copy looked nearly identical, a fact that wasn't wasted when I reached for the stone foot, nearly as pretty as the real thing. In fact, aside from the lack of gold nail polish, I might have mistaken the smooth pale stone for Qumsal's real foot. Pushing down, I felt a bit of resistance as the rock sank into the pedestal. I heard a lot of movement behind the wall, and when I looked back at Maddie I saw the golden feathers retreat into the statue's stomach while the arms lowered my still giggling friend to the ground.

It took a few seconds, but eventually Maddie's toes and their sky-blue nails touched the floor. When she was standing firmly on her feet, the statue's hands let go and returned to what I assumed was their original position. Giggles still escaped her lips, but for the most part she had recovered from the embarassing assault on her butt. Wiping the tears from her face, she looked up in what was at first an expression of surprise, then relief as she pulled me for one of the biggest hugs I've ever received.

"Oh my god, I thought you were gone! I've been looking for you for so long, I thought they'd gotten you for good! And then I stepped into this trap, and I thought we were gonna be stuck here forever!" She pulled back and smiled at me, and for a second I thought she might start crying again. "I'm so glad that you weren't taken, thank you so much..."

Suddenly, she noticed that someone else was watching and turned to face Qumsal, who had been standing there and watching us the entire time. I could see a deceptively warm smile on her face, but I could feel that she was amused at the reunion. I blushed a little, slightly embarassed, but if Qumsal was helping us I could count her a a friend, so overall it wasn't that shaming.

"Um..." Maddie began nervously, all traces of her joy replaced by a sudden fear and a hint of distress. "Who's she?"

Just as I was about to introduce her, the sorceress spoke up and did it herself. "I am Qumsal, Guardian of the Sands and the one who helped free both you and your friend."

The reaction was instantaneous. Maddie jumped back, wary and scared of the nubile woman who stood calmly and expectantly, as if she knew she would react this way. My timid friend began walking back slowly, her entire body trying to shy away from the sorceress. "You're... you're..."

"It's alright Maddie," I said reassuringly, putting a hand on her shoulder. "Qumsal has agreed to help us stop T'Calu's return. She already freed me from the trap, and I believe we can trust her." I didn't mention that Qumsal had been the one to tie me up and set the feather on me in the first place, or what I had to offer to ger her to agree, but those were things she didn't need to know. As it was, I was half afraid she might turn and run for it, but luckily that fear was unfounded as Maddie turned to face our new ally.

"Are you sure?" she asked, still hesitant.

I answered with a firm nod of my head. "I trust her completely." A half-truth, but if it would get Maddie to trust her then it served its purpose.

Still cautious, Maddie slowly approached Qumsal, who was still smiling. The two looked at each other for some time while Maddie drew closer, reaching out her hand for a shake when she got close enough. "M-my name is Maddie," she stammered. "Good t-to meet you, Q-Qumsal."

Chuckling, Qumsal reached out as if to take the offered hand, but she missed it completely and kept going. "This is how we greeted people in my time," she explained mysteriously. Both Maddie and I were confused, until I noticed where Qumsal's hand would end up. The sorceress' long and pointy nails snaked underneath  Maddie's sweater and made contact with her side, pinching and kneading the skin. The effect was spontaneous. Maddie backed away, giggling, Qumsal's fingers still working on her soft skin. It surprised me, but what happened next surprised me more.

Just as I was about to tell Qumsal to stop, Maddie darted her hands forward and started fiddling with her Qumsal's sides. It was obvious Qumsal wasn't expecting it either as she nearly doubled over before responding my reaching out and tickling Maddie's other side. Both were locked in this tickling circle, Qumsal's musical laughter and Maddie's cute giggles filling the passage. Honestly, I was having a good time just watching.

After a few minutes when it was clear neither of them were giving up, I decided enough was enough. "Alright you two, stop it," I tried, but they kept at it, both hunched over trying to protect their ticklish torsos. I had to step between them before they would finally break the chain. "Knock it off, we have stuff to do!"

"Why are you complaining?" Maddie asked with a spirit I didn't expect from her. "I thought you were into tickling and all that?" Too late, I realized that while she was talking Maddie had snuck her hands to my own sides and were now working on them like she was with Qumsal's, tickling the skin with gentle but firm pinches.

Laughing, I recoiled and stepped backwards... right into Qumsal. "She's not nearly as ticklish as you, young master," she told me. "Your sensitivity is much more enjoyable." With that, she reached around me and started kneading my ribs. Instinctively I tried to back up, but my back was already against Qumsal's body and she wasn't letting me go anywhere. Left with nothing to do but laugh, that's exactly what I did, my arms trying but failing to push either set of hands away.

To be honest, there were worse positions to be in than at the hands of a very pretty childhood friend and a beautiful young woman. Then again, the situation was a little urgent.
1142111221221112212111.title: Meet and Greet

choices: We came to a large circular room
11421112212211122121112.content:
Finding the energy to push off my attackers, I quickly stumbled away. Neither of them chased me, just smirked at me, amused and quite content with their fun. I took a few seconds to recover, then tried to shift their attention back to the task at hand. "Have you girls had enough?"

"No," Qumsal admitted, "but I'm willing to wait until you're in a more submissive mood."

"I'm done for now," Maddie snickered. It was different having Maddie so confident, maybe this misadventure was having a larger effect than I'd thought. Her eyes wandered, and her inevitable discovery of my nudity occurred. "Um..." she said, all her usual shyness returning, her cheeks flushing as well, "why are you naked?"

"Good question," I agreed, looking at Qumsal intently. "Why am I naked?" It wasn't that embarrassing, but I felt like I needed to take a verbal stab at my former tormentor.

As serious as ever, she shrugged. "You are easier to tickle that way, young master. Besides, what little clothing you wore was too badly shredded by your ride down the chute to serve its original purpose."

Honestly, I wasn't expecting such a straightforward answer. Maddie looked at me inquisitively but decided not to ask anything. Deciding that we should probably move on, I moved over to where Maddie's pants laid in tatters and picked up the book. "This is what I was telling you about Qumsal," I informed her. "You can look at it later, but right now we should continue looking for the Orb of Ethereal."

"You are going though greater trouble than is required, young master," Qumsal told me. Both Maddie and I shared surprised glances. We weren't quite sure how to take that.

"What do you mean?" I asked.

"True, removing the Orb will deny the portal the pure magical energies required to activate, but there is a much simpler way to prevent the portal from opening," the sorceress explained. "There is a talisman that is also necessary for the portal to activate, a spherical yellow stone engraved with T'Calu's emblem for sand on it. Without the talisman, the passage through realms cannot maintain a physical connection with this portal. The talisman is much easier to remove than the Orb much more rewarding as well."

"Rewarding?" I said curiously. "How so?"

"When adorned, it will grant a small amount of magical power to the wearer, tied to the essences of vast deserts and sands. How this magic will take shape I cannot say, only that it will be a boon if you wish to continue fighting T'Calu."

Again, Maddie and I exchanged glances. This entire time, there had been an easier way to fix this problem? Removing the orb sounded easy at the time, but now we had a much more defined course of action. Having Qumsal to help us was already paying off.

"Sounds good," I said, happy that we now knew what we were doing. "I assume you know the way?"

"Indeed, young master. The portal is in a chamber the lowermost level of this temple, large enough for ten of T'Calu's warbeasts two fit through side by side. Come, I will lead you," she informed us, turning and walking down the hallway we just came from, me following her and Madie following somewhat hesitantly after me.

The first few minutes of our journey were in silence, then Maddie clung to my arm and began whispering. "Are you this is such a good idea? She does work for T'Calu."

"No, now she works for me, more or less. We have an agreement I think we're both quite happy with," I told her. It only made sense for her to be suspicious, after all she was seemingly randomly tickled when she tried to shake hands, but I had hoped I could've convinced her with my earlier statements.

Grumbling softly, Maddie accepted my words albeit grudgingly and fell quiet again. Our travelling was largely uneventful until...
11421112212211122121112.title: Time to Go

choices: Yet another challenge awaited us in the room
The statue moved, leading into another chamber
114211122122111221211122.content:
After what felt like half an hour of walking, a lot of it retracing the steps Qumsal and I took to find Maddie, we came to a dead-end. It was a good-looking dead-end, a big circular chamber with six Qumsal look-alike statues lining the wall. Each one stood on a pedestal embedded with a precious stone of various colors: a deep purple amethyst, a sparkling green emerald, a mesmerizing blue sapphire, a bright red ruby, a solid black onyx, and some lively yellow citrine. At the end of the room, opposite the passage we just entered from, a gigantic stone tablet covered part of the wall, letters of some ancient dialect engraved on the rock. The seemingly random dots and sratches reminded me a bit of sand, the way the small grains move about in a sandstorm.

Upon realizing there was no exit, Maddie immediately began shouting. "I knew it, you've led us into a trap, haven't you?" she accused, pointing harshly at Qumsal. "Everything you've said was a lie, and this is where a bunch of traps or monsters jump out and tickle us into submission!"

Our guide turned to face us and crossed her arms. "Then tell me young fool, why has it not happened yet?" Qumsal replied, still seemingly patient but I could sense the irritation in her demeanor, as did Maddie, who glared at the soreress before us. "None of the mindless creatures are able to wait more than a few seonds upon seeing an intruder without rushing the person, eager to detain and tickle them. You can search the room if you like, but you will find neither creature nor trap here that I have led you to."

Hmph-ing, Maddie actually did as Qumsal suggested and walked to the nearest statue, searching behind it and to either side before moving onto the next one. For some reason I felt like she wasn't going to be satisfied until she checked every one as well as making sure the tablet wasn't a trap or anything. She inspeted the gemstone, the statue, the pedestal, behind it all. When she didn't find anything, she moved onto the next one. I couldn't blame her for being jumpy and overly cautious, but why would Qumsal take us this far just to tickle us? I'm sure there were plenty of opportunities along the way.

"Young master," Qumsal spoke in a quiet tone, "beyond this point I cannot lead you with any confidence. I was only assigned to protect this labyrinth. If there is another below, I will be useless."

"Why?" I asked. "Aren't you basically the high-priestess here or something?

"Nothing nearly so garish as that. I was simply in charge of the affairs of the temple after it was built, they did not consult me when they were drafting the floor plans. They gave me a map of the temple that was considered mine, and they told that the portal lies beyond this room yet told me nothing of how to get there. It was not my duty to know." Qumsal paused and glanced at Maddie, who was inspecting the third statue, before leaning in close to my ear. "May I confide something in you, young master?" she asked, her voice having dropped.

"What is it?"

"It is your companion, Maddie. I am concerned. In here, everything is to do with T'Calu's influence, hence everything has to do with tickling. In this civilization, sensitivity was held in high regard and the more ticklish one was the more worthy one was. They probably built this temple with the same mindset, which will make Maddie a liability. She is ticklish, what we have previously witnessed proves that, but not nearly as ticklish as you or I. I remember first being caught in that trap, and I was howling much louder than she was." - I filed that information away in my head - "That, and she does not trust me, which is both very annoying and time-consuming. I do not like people who distrust their allies, it does not do wonders for a team."

"Maddie has good reason to be suspicious," I countered. "We came here wanting to avoid T'Calu's minions, and until recently you were the most powerful one here. She's still getting used to that, cut her some slack."

I could tell Qumsal was about to protest, but before she could I quickly reached out and pinched her hips, hushing whatever she might have said. A surprised girlish "Eep!" escaped her lips and whatever protests she had were lost in the ensuing giggles. She did not resist though, spreading her hands as if to invite more. As tempted as I was to continue, every minute counted, so I stopped and focused again on the task at hand, much to Qumsal's obvious disappointment.

"Do you think you can read that?" I asked, gesturing to the tablet. "It might hold a clue as to how we continue."

Nodding, Qumsal approached the giant stone slab, peering at the writing. Maddie had finished her fifth statue right now, and began her inspection of the sixth. After a minute, Qumsal reported what she could. "Unfortunately young master, most of it is unintelligible garbling. Time has worn away the engravings, but not to the point where I cannot read the characters. Below the top line, they are arranged erratically and nonsensically. Only the top line is readable. It says 'To continue to the Gateway of Sands, take the hands of the Guardian who is missing their tool.' Obviously it is hinting at something, though I have yet to figure it out."

"Well what is that supposed to mean?" Maddie asked, now finally done with her inspection and finding nothing.

Already I was thinking about what the tablet said. The Guardian who was missing a tool? Well, Qumsal was the Guardian, though I wasn't sure whether she had any tools. But the tablet referred to Guardians, plural. Then it hit me. All six of the statues were exact replicas of Qumsal, and were arguably Guardians themselves. Mabe "take the hands of" literally meant grasping the hands of the statue who was missing a tool, something Qumsal had.

"What if the Guardians the tablet is referring to are these statues," I voiced my thoughts, "and we have to grab the hands of whichever one is missing this tool?"

"That makes sense!" Maddie said excitedly, then she frowned in thought. "Though if we're choosing the one that is missing a tool, well, that would be all of them, since none of them have tools or anything."

Before I could voice my next thought, Qumsal interjected with her own solution. "No, the tablet is phrased to ask which statue is missing their tool. I do not use any physical tools, as you can see, so none of them are missing tools. In which case the answer is none."

"What about-" I started before being abruptly cut off again.

"Then how do we pull hands that don't exist, oh Guardian?" Maddie asked sarcastically with a surprising amount of attitude in her voice.

"And how do you propose we pull all of the hands, young fool?" Qumsal quipped back. An ugly arguement was brewing, and I wanted nothing to do with it.

As the two went back and forth, I inspected the statues, trying to confirm my earlier thought. I walked up to each one, looking at their hands, trying to ignore the din in the background. The first few tries proved unsuccessful, but just as I was about to give up hope I found what I was looking for. One of the statues was missing its ring, the one with a feather engraved on it on Qumsal's left hand. I felt the bare smooth stone, and looked at the remaining statue, which had its own ring. I was confident this was the right one.

"You're right," I heard Maddie shout distinctively and I turned to look. "All of the Guardians are missing tools. Including this one!" Suddenly Maddie darted her fingers forward and began worming them into Qumsal's sides, minimally protected by the sheer thin garment that looked useless at protecting aganst a tickle attack. Qumsal squealed rather unceremoniously and broke into incohesive babbling among her incessant giggles, try to bat Maddie's arms away but only succeeding in making Maddie more determined. The tickling forced Qumsal to the tablet until her back made contact with the stone slab and she had nowhere to run. Of course, Maddie took full advantage, letting her hands wander and explore new areas. She raked her fingers across Qumsal's ribs, which caused the sorceress to shriek loudly. She pinched and kneaded Qumsal's hips, which caused the sorceress to grind her rear into the tablet in a futile escape attempt. I enjoyed the show for a minute or two, but I grew irritated after a while.

Deciding this had gone on long enough, I grabbed the statue's hands and pulled. The arms moved, and the scraping stone was loud enough to get the two girls' attention.
114211122122111221211122.title: Puzzling Puzzles

1142111221221112212111221.content:
The rumbling continued for another minute or two, eventually drawing Maddie away from her assault, leaving a giggling Qumsal to recover on her own.. When the noise stopped, Maddie and I looked around expectantly for a door or something. There was none however, and I became a little saddened. I was so confident that I'd gotten it right.

"Drat," I exclaimed rather loudly. "I was sure that was the right one."

"Well something happened," Maddie pointed out optimistically, "and since no traps went off I assume that whatever happened was a good thing. Let's look around, maybe there's a switch or something that got revealed."

Nodding in agreement, both Maddie and I began searching the circular chamber, looking for any differences. I checked the pedestals to see if a rocky button had appeared or something, but they were all as sleek as before. At last managing to subdue her giggles, Qumsal joined our search for something that indicated a way out. We had no idea what we were looking for, which made it that much harder to find it. Just as we were on the verge of giving up, Qumsal peered at the tablet once more.

"Young master," she called, grabbing my attention. Maddie and I turned and saw that Qumsal had her finger on the tablet, as if to keep her place in the text. "Some of the characters have reordered themselves, I can read the next few passages."

"Really? What does it say?" I asked, getting an idea of how this worked.

Qumsal spent a few more seconds following the words before answering. "Most of it is just praises of T'Calu, telling of her greatness in civilizations past, but the last line is a riddle-like question similar to the first. 'Take the hands of the Guardian whose gemstone matches the color of our goddess,' it reads."

"So that's what the precious stones are for," I mused, looking at the embedded minerals with rekindled interest. "Though what does 'match the color of our goddess' mean?"

"Maybe it means we need to pick the color that we think symbolizes T'Calu?" Maddie suggested. I nodded my agreement, and Maddie smiled and took that as her que to bring forward an idea. Taking another look at the pedestals, she approached the decorative onyx curiously. "It's probably black," she thought aloud. "T'Calu has lots of temples of various civilizations dedicated to her. Each one probably has it's own color to celebrate her. Since black is sort of all the colors at once..."

"Good reasoning," I told her, but a recent memory was bubbling up and again I had my own answer. "Though I think it's actually-"

"I disagree," Qumsal interjected, cutting me off. "Throughout this entire temple, throughout this entire city in fact, T'Calu has always been celebrated and depicted with yellow, the color of the sand on a bright day. We actually used citrine as an offering on multiple occasions. Everything points to the statue with the yellow citrine embedded at its feet."

"But this is just one of the many cities that honored T'Calu as their goddess," Maddie argued. "I'm sure there are some temples that honored her just as greatly using other colors, and since we can't pull every pair of hands we should go for black, which is when the material absorbs all the other colors!"

"That may very well be, but we are not in any of the other temples. We are in this one, and this temple celebrated her with the color yellow," Qumsal quipped, a frown beginning to crease her face. "Here, citrine is the way we worship our goddess because its color matches her's, it is the correct answer!"

"Um, ladies, I think-"

"I know black is right!" Maddie huffed, stropping over to the onyx statue. "And I'm gonna prove it when we get out of here!"

"Maddie, wait!" I shouted, too late to stop her. Maddie grabbed the hands of the statue and yanked as hard as she could, starting another fit of rumbling. Before she could look triumphant however, the statue's hands quickly latched onto my friend's wrists and hoisted her into the air so that her feet dangled just above the pedestal. The rumbling continued, and the front of the pedestal turned out to be a stone hatch that slid into the floor, exposing a hole beneath the statue. From that hole emerged a cluster of golden feathers attached to the end of a stick - sort of like a mop - that extended until it made contact with Maddie's feet, causing her toes to wiggle furiously.

"Wha-what happened?" Maddie asked nervously.

"What happened," Qumsal answered deceptively calmly, "is that you guessed wrong. And it appears there is a punishment for incorrect answers." Her voice seemed indifferent, but I could sense the relish underneath her demeanor.

"I'm sorry, Maddie," I shrugged apologetically. "I tried to warn you."

"What? What do youEEP!" she suddenly shrieked as the feathery mop began rotating, brushing the cluster of feathers across the soles of Maddie's feet. "Nohohhohohostahahahahap!" she cried uselessly, kicking her feet to avoid the feathers. That worked for some time, until two more hatches in the statue's shins opened up to reveal a pair of wooden clasps that clamped onto Maddie's feet and pulled them down, forcing them back onto the cluster of feathers that continued spinning deliberately. "Nahahahahaha!" she continued laughing, now unable to hide from the trap.

"Perhaps we should help teach her as well, young master?" Qumsal suggested, stalking closer to Maddie's helpless body. Part of me just wanted to press on, but my urges got the better of me and I found myself following Qumsal to the scene.

An amused smirk had spread across the sorceress' face as she reached forward with her fingers. "Feathers were quite potent, but now let's see how you react to these," she teased, just before flicking her long sharp nails across Maddie's behind. Caught completely by surprise, Maddie gave a single piercing shriek before devolving into frenzied laughter and thrust her hips forward, but Qumsal saw it coming and followed with expert ease. With the shock of the new attack more or less over, Qumsal settled for lazy dragging the tips of her nails across Maddie's panty-clad bottom. If it weren't so damn fun to watch, I might've felt sorry for Maddie. Qumsal really knew what she was doing. As for me, I went around to the front of my laughing friend, I reaching up and slipping my hands underneathe her sweater. Maddie shook her head and screamed helplessly, still thrashing her rump in an attempt to throw off Qumsal's fingers. My only response was to grin and start gently running my fingers over her belly.

"Maybe this'll teach you to listen before doing something headstrong," I lectured her, emphasizing the point by sticking a finger in her bellybutton and swirling it around. I was rewarded with a series of shrieks and squirms, happy to let my finger draw them out for as long as I could. My other hand went up and started counting her ribs, pinching each one underneath the worn fabric of her sweater. As Maddie hung there laughing, I was beginning to forget about the bigger issue we were dealing with amidst all the fun.
1142111221221112212111221.title: Lesson #1 - Listen to me

11421112212211122121112211.content:
After a few short minutes, both the feather mop and the wooden clasps returned to within the statue, the stone hatches grinding shut again. Slowly, the statue lowered Maddie to the ground before returning to its original position, leaving her a giggling wreck on the floor.

Stepping forward, I looked down and put a hand on her shoulder."Hey, you okay?" I asked tentatively. What we'd put her through was rather harsh I realized, much more rigorous than I had originally intended. Qumsal didn't look the least bit apologetic though, I fact that I didn't miss.

When I turned Maddie's face towards mine, I was met with a cheeky smile. "Yohou're sohoho mehehean," she giggled softly, poking me in the side and making me giggle myself. Happy that we hadn't gone too far, I helped her up so that we could continue the puzzle.

"Now that this business has concluded," Qumsal stated, "I believe it is time for us to continue."

"Hold on," I said, though I seemed to have gone unheard. As she walked towards the statue with citrine at its feet, I frowned in thought. Something was bugging me. I knew the answer to this puzzle, I did! I just... Then something clicked. A memory of a forest, when I went through the Gateway and entered T'Calu's realm. The color of the room, the color of the goddess herself. I knew the answer.

"Um, Qumsal, I think..." I began, then I realized that Qumsal was already at the statue, reaching up. "Wait!" I yelled, knowing it was too late.

Qumsal pulled on the stony hands, and a few rumbling seconds later she was suspended in the air exactly like Maddie was, feet dangling in level with the pedestal. The front of the pedestal slid into the floor, reavealing another mop of golden feathers that extended and brushed Qumsal's delicate feet, at which she giggled briefly. Then the hatches in the rocky shins opened up, letting two wooden devices reach forward and clamp around the sorceress' ankles, this time letting the anticipation of being tickled do its work before starting.

"Oh my," Qumsal whispered, though she appeared slightly less shaken than Maddie had.

"Looks like someone else guessed wrong as well," Maddie quipped snidely, barely able to contain her contempt. "And as we all know, there is a punishment for incorrect answers." I raised my eyebrows. This was a different Maddie than the girl who shyly hid her face beneath some bangs.

As if the trap was listening, the golden feathers chose that moment to start rotating, swiping bristle after bristle across Qumsal's creamy soles. Immediately she burst out in peals of musical laughter, trying her best to hide one foot with the other and swapping every few seconds. The wooden restraints soon got wise to her tactic however, and the clamps pulled her ankles apart slightly so that she could no longer cross her feet and both were subjected to the incredibly tickly feathers. Qumsal shook her head, laughing deeply at the trap. She wasn't lying about being more ticklish than Maddie.

"Time to give you a taste of your own medicine," Maddie teased, wasting no time in approaching Qumsal's equally if not more helpless body. "Now let's see how you like it." Then, remembering the sorceress' tactful approach, she gently flicked her fingers across Qumsal's full buns, earning a girlish squeal with each flick. The sorceress was now trying to escape a second tormentor, shaking her hips from side to side but never really getting away from Maddie's vengeful fingers. "Looks as if I'm not the only one with a ticklish tush. Well, am I right, Guardian?" Maddie asked rhetorically, flicking all ten fingers across Qumsal's rump. Naturally, her only response was another squeal, louder and longer than her previous ones.

Sighing, I climbed the statue in front of Qumsal and stood before her. She looked at me with a face contorted with laughter, tears beginning to leak from her eyes. I suppose that she really was very ticklish. "You two really need to learn to listen to me," I scolded. "I usually have my own ideas, and you'd be surprised how much I know." Without further ado, I reached forward and softly began tracing my fingertips down Qumsal's silky smooth arms. Knowing my destination, she began shaking her head wildly, a tear trailing down her cheek as I gently spider-tickled my fingers down to her underarms, barely touching the olive-colored skin in her hollows. Her laughter rocketed up in volume, as did her struggles. Now she was shaking all over, twisting every which way to avoid whatever tickles she could. Amused by the reaction, I left one hand in her underarm while letting the other trail down to her belly and ribs, fingers scuttling everywhere.

During their random squibbles one finger accidently slipped into her bellybutton, and although she was wearing a dress Qumsal still shrieked loudly. Looking up at the sound, Maddie grinned at me, never ceasing her torturous flicks and wiggles. "Oooh," she said. "She likes that!" Nodding in agreement, I soon had a grin of my own as I sent that little finger back to where it found the little divet. It took a bit of searching, but pretty soon my finger was deep inside Qumsal's navel, worming around and earning a mixture of belly laughs and helpless shrieks. A few more tears now trickled down the sorceress' face, falling into her open mouth that never stopped laughing.

A few more minutes passed, and eventually Qumsal was let down as well, much to Maddie's disappointment. She kept flicking her fingers across Qumsal's rear cheeks, switching to her sides when the sorceress hid her bum on the floor, until a harsh glare from me finally got her to stop. The woman sat there, drying her eyes, shaking every now and then.

I kneeled down so that I could apologize, Qumsal's body still twitching under my outstretched palm. When our eyes met, I was surprised to see an excited glint in her gray ones. Standing up from her position on the floor, she looked down at my still wide eyes and said, "Promise me that you will do that often, young master, and I will be yours forever." I was shocked, and guessing by Maddie's gaping mouth, so was she. "Well, you have your own answer do you not?" Qumsal continued. "I believe we have wasted enough time here."

Nodding, I quickly got up and marched to the amethyst. I remembered that in T'Calu's little meeting room, the theme was purple and black. I was torn between those two colors, but the goddess herself was purple so I assumed that was the better choice. And also, black was eliminated when Maddie guessed it and guessed wrong. Confidently, I reached up to the statues hands and pulled.
11421112212211122121112211.title: Lesson #2 - LISTEN TO ME!

114211122122111221211122112.content:
Another round of rumbling began, and judging by how I wasn't being strung up by my hands and being tickled by golden feathers I assumed that my guess was correct. This time however, something happened that was easy to see. In the middle of the circular chamber, a large hole opened and from it rose a table-sized block of stone. At each corner was U-shaped semi-ring of rock, for what purposes I could guess. Directly above it, a diamond suspended by a chain lowered itself from a smaller hole in the center of the ceiling. At least, I think it was a diamond. It was certainly as pretty as one, though it shone whiter than a pearl. When the rumbling stopped, the stone block sat a couple feet above the ground and the diamond-thingy hung a few feet above that. We all spent another few seconds admiring the perfection of the dangling gemstone.

I looked at Qumsal, who in turn looked at the tablet. Without hesitation, she began following the new words that had reshaped, reading what was previously illegible scribbles. "Most of what has been rearranged heralds the return of T'Calu, speaking of her glories and telling of the laughter she will bring to her enemies," Qumsal said. "Again, the only line of any significance to our current situation is the last one: 'Lie down on the bed of stone and laugh until the mirth crystal is filled.' Ah, so no matter how knowledgeable one is, they must have endurance to make it past this point."

"What exactly does that mean?" I asked, though I could figure it out well enough.

"Well, young master, that hanging stone is referred to as a mirth crystal, a gemstone capable of absorbing and storing mirth magic. It also possesses the ability to transform some of the mirth magic into base magic should such a form be required. My guess is that shifting the text on the tablet and activating the traps took a certain amount of magic to activate, as will opening the way to the portal. One of us must offer ourselves on that stone table and be tickled until the mirth crystal is full before we may continue."

"Great," I exclaimed. "That means the traps you two set off drained the crystal even more, making the time for whoever gets on that longer than necessary. See what happens when you ladies don't talk to me?"

The two of them looked slightly abashed, though Qumsal was rather good at hiding it. She could not help but blush a tad bit from embarassment, remembering her incorrect guess and rather admonishing experience. "If it pleases you, young master," she offered, "I will be the one to fill the mirth crystal. On the condition that your friend refrains from joining whatever administers the tickling."

"No promises, Guardian," Maddie said.

"That's fine, I'll do it," I told them, surprising them both and earning a couple sets of raised eyebrows. "You two have had pretty tiring experiences already, I think it's my turn to take some."

"But, young master, you should not have to pay for our mistakes," Qumsal protested. "We made them so one of us should pay."

"Actually, I'm with the Guardian on this one, you don't have to be all macho and take a few tickles for us," Maddie agreed, looking a little worried.

Touched by their concern, I took a step forward... and tickled them. One hand goosed Maddie's exposed hip, the other fluttered aross Qumsal's tummy. In no time flat the two were on the floor, doing their best to protect themselves while shying away from my devious fingers. Chuckling, I stood back and watched them huddle a bit before shaking themselves off. "You two are still tired - and sensitized - from being caught in those traps. Nah, I think I'll take this one."

Standing up, Qumsal smiled and gently poked my side, provoking an unbecoming squeak. "Thank you, young master," she said, warmth emanating from her soft grey eyes.

"Yeah, thanks," Maddie said, standing up and pulling me in for a hug, smiling. It still struck me how attractive she was when she did that, though I'd seen her smile countless times before. Returning her hug, I couldn't help but tweak her ribs once, causing Maddie to back away giggling.

Smiling back at them, I turned and climbed onto the relatively low-lying stone block. Now knowing what they were for, I slipped my wrists into the two U-shaped rocks at top of the table before repeating the action with my ankles at the bottom. All four closed on my limbs with the sound of scraping stone, pulling towards the corners and stretching me out as far as I would go. Before the tugging could become painful, the stone cuffs relaxed, leaving me with little wriggle room to work with. Not that I minded - I'd been in harsher conditions and loved it. Qumsal and Maddie, with nothing to really do, sat on the ground, and the three of us waited for something to happen.

The silence was broken by the sound of cracking stone to my left. Turning in that direction, I saw one of the Qumsal statues come to life and step off of her pedestal. She stretched her hands high over her head as if just waking up from a long slumber, and though they were made of stone I could not help but stare at the smooth underarms. Whoever made these statues had an eye for detail, and the stone renditions of the Guardian were so life-like the sculptor must have had Qumsal in the room while carving them. Another rocky crack bounced off the circular walls, and the statue right beside the now-active one also stirred, flexing her back and slinking her body off the pedestal (yes, I am now referring to the statues as shes, get over it, the original is very hot). The third crack came from my right, and as I spun my head around that way I witnessed a comical scene. One of the statues hopped off the pedestal and shook herself as if just getting out of a cold shower, an amusing motion considering she was not wet. Looking around, her eyes met mine and a smile sprad across herr full rocky lips.

Maddie and Qumsal watched in wonder and astonishment, though Qumsal was more intrigued than amazed. She had seen magic many times before I imagined, it was the ingenuity and the craftsmanship of whoever weaved this spell that caught her interest. "A most useful spell," she mused. "Animation is often heard of but rarely used, probably because of the steep price in terms of magical energy. Young master, you are going to be tickled for a while. Again, I apologize for acting hastily, though to tell the truth I am going to enjoy watching this a lot." That made me gulp, and I was wondering whether I was going to get a little bit more than I had bargained for.

Soon, six attractive Qumsal-statues stood around me smiling, taking a few seconds to take in my restrained form. One reached over and traced her fingers across my hip, eliciting a jolt and a giggle, and the six of them looked at each other with what looked like excitement in their eyes (it was hard to tell since they were made of stone), some even clapping excitedly. I found it ironic that whilst they all looked exactly like Qumsal, they acted like polar opposites. Whereas Qumsal was restrained and mature, these statues seemed giddy and barely able to suppress their enthusiasm, actually failing altogether. Another one flicked her nails (just as sharp as the original's) across my sole, causing me to wiggle my foot and giggle again. A similar reaction spread around the group, exchanged glances and eager faces ready to begin work.
114211122122111221211122112.title: What we do for friends

1142111221221112212111221121.content:
"What are these statues, Qumsal?" I asked, staring curiously at the gang of statues who were cooing at me. All six of them were pushing, shoving, and almost wrestling with each other as they fought over which spot they would 'claim'. To be honest, it was quite amusing.

"As you can see, young master, they are duplicates of my own exquisite form," Qumsal explained. Maddie scoffed, earning Qumsal's attention. "But their demeanor is somewhat less... restrained. The sculptor - a powerful sorcerer - was one of the best I've ever met, and captured my image perfectly," she said, glaring at Maddie and wiggling her fingers threateningly towards her. Maddie stuck her tongue out and wiggled her fingers back.

"Why are they so unrestrained?" I asked, observing two of the statues fight over my feet.

"Well, the sculptor always used his magic to imbue his works with personality, and he preferred spirited girls. Nonetheless, they certainly seem enthusiastic, and are very likely as proficient as myself," Qumsal answered, and I couldn't help but notice the excited tone in her voice, her gray eyes gleaming.

"By the way, thanks again for taking one for the team!" Maddie said much too cheerily."We appreciate it!" she added with a sly smile. All this tickling had changed her so greatly from the shy reserved girl I knew for years. I wondered if she was going to enjoy the show as well. Probably, I figured.

"Yeah, uh, you're welcome," I replied, watching two statues fight over who would get to play with my belly. As amusing as it was to watch, I was annoyed because all this waiting kept me in suspense for a while until one of them was victorious and claimed the spot.

Now there were two statues clapping her fingers in excitement at my feet, two statues giggling at my underarms, one statues flexing her fingers at my sides and one statue hovering over my stomach smacking her lips. It seems the statues couldn't resist for long, and before I could brace myself began tickling in reckless abandon. They showed no restraint, seemingly very eager to quickly tickle as much laughter out of me as possible.

The two at my underarms exploited my complete vulnerability, ten fingers spider-tickling in each one, sometimes grazing along and teasing the edges before burying back into the center. A single nail in one underarm spiraled in slowly, attacked the center of my hollow, then spiraled out again slowly before repeating. The two manning my mid-section were unbearable. One statue was squeezing my hips, which alone excited me due to its proximity to my groin, and the other was poking and prodding all along my bare stomach and sides. My navel was, at one time, subjected to an adventurous stony fingernail. The last two were exploring my trapped feet, their nimble long fingers scampering all over my soles as if they were trying to tickle the whole foot at once.

To make things more intense, all six of them had razor-sharp fingernails that were roving all over my trapped body. They also seemed to titter and giggle the more I laughed, as if they having a great amount of fun at my expense. For some reason hearing them chuckle would make me laugh more, and then the cycle would repeat itself.

As I laughed, I noticed barely visible multicolored lines rising from the part of my body being tickled and floating up to the mirth crystal. The sight would have been entrancing were I not being severely tickled by a gang of giddy living statues. I assumed this was the physical form of my mirth essence or whatever filling the crystal.

"Hahahahowwww muhumuch more?" I laughed, barely about to form a coherent sentence will sixty fingers stimulating my sensitive body all over.

"The mirth crystal is almost half full, young master," Qumsal said, glancing up at the crystal. Shortly after that, the statues stopped moving and all looked at each other, wide grins on their faces. I was grateful for the break as I caught my breath, looking between my tormentresses nervously.

"What... are they... doing?" I asked between pants.

"I don't know, young master, though it looks as though they may be discussing tactics," Qumsal replied, looking curiously at the statues. As I looked next to her, I was surprised to see Maddie doing something similar. Apparently both of them were enjoying themselves and were eager to see more. A few minutes passed, followed by the stony guardians returning to their places and giggling mutely, all licking their lips. I soon worked out why they were giggling when I felt one of the statues blow a raspberry on my stomach. 

"BAHAHAHAHAHA!" I cackled, erupting with laughter as I felt tongues make contact with my skin. It was a strange feeling, being statues they had no saliva but their tongues were still slick and tickly. They could also still rather effective at blowing raspberries. 

This was a new kind of tickling, far more intense as I felt tongues trail up my feet. They even occasionally nibbled at my toes with their teeth, the pinching sensations shooting arcs of electricity though my nerves. The pair suckling at my underarms was horrifically tickly, made all the more worse that I couldn't pull my arms down at all, leaving them open and exposed. The pair dragging their tongues all over my quivering stomach drove me mad as I felt like a pair of snakes were slithering all over my torso. Tears of laughter formed in my eyes as one of the statues slipped her tongue into my navel and wiggled it all about, hitting the bottom and walls. Through bleary eyes, I saw that the trail of mirth essence from my belly was nearly a flood, a thick solid chord connecting my bellybutton to the crystal.

Thankfully, one good thing about oral tickling was that because it was far more intense, it drew much more laughter from me and before long the crystal was full, gleaming with rainbow colors, an iridescent gemstone shining with light. Their jobs finished, the statues returned to their pedestals, seeming to sigh with disappointment that they had finished with me already. As the last one mounted her pedestal, I swear I saw her wink before freezing in the same position as her sister, the room looking more or less like it had when we first came in.

Maddie and Qumsal stood up and walked over to my panting form. There was no way for me to see, but both were wearing rather devious smiles.

"That looked quite enjoyable, young master," Qumsal commented. "Perhaps you would like it to continue?"

"Wait... what?" I said, still breathless. 

"I mean, you had a lot of fun tickling the two of us, didn't you? Surely it's only fair we get a little bit of payback," Maddie clarified with a big smirk on her face. She wiggled her fingers menacingly at me, and I tried to get up. The stone cuffs hadn't opened yet, leaving me at the mercy of two tickle-hungry dames. "Y'see? We can get along fine. Qumsal, would you like to share?" Maddie asked, gesturing to my still stretched out and exposed body.

"Now, ladies..." I warned, before Qumsal put a sharp finger with golden varnish over my mouth.

"It seems that your friend and I are in mutual agreement. We both wish to hear your laughter, so we will make you laugh," she smiled as she took my left side while Maddie took my right.

Now this was certainly something else, being tormented by a shy cutie on one side and a tickle-loving sorceress on the other. As I looked from Maddie's excited face to Qumsal's eager face, I resigned myself to the tickling, knowing that there was nothing I could do. And the fact that I was stretched out naked about to be tickled by two beautiful women already started turning me on, a fact that was rather plain to see stark naked as I was.

Without any pretense, both started tickling me at the same time as if they had shared some silent countdown. It seemed that Maddie had picked up a few tricks as she and Qumsal blew raspberries on my vulnerable belly, earning peals of frantic laughter. Maddie tormenting my left flank, tickling in reckless abandon by shooting her fingers everywhere and digging into my hips and ribs, while Qumsal teased my right, gentle flicks and pinches across my skin, was both incredibly ticklish and unbearably hot. Thankfully after a few more minutes of this, the stone cuffs opened as if finally realizing that I was still trapped. Instantly I pulled all my limbs in and covered as much of myself a I could. Good thing too, I didn't think I would have been able to take much more, in more ways than one.

"Now wasn't that fun?" one of them asked. I expected it to be Qumsal, but to my surprise it was Maddie, offering me a hand.

"Definitely, though maybe it should one of you on the slab next time," I replied, with a mischievous grin. That earned me a poke in the sides from both of them. I poked them both back, and the three of us stared at the tablet, giggling slightly as it spun back to reveal...
1142111221221112212111221121.title: Sextuple-Teamed

choices: I retrieved the talisman and we made our retreat.
It wasn't going to be that easy...
11421112212211122121112211211.content:
Another bout of rumbling ensued as the giant stone tablet slowly opened, sand cascading off the top as it slid backwards into the hidden passageway. The noise of stone scraping against stone echoed throughout the chamber as the giant chunk of rock dragged across the sandy floor. Maddie and I shared a look of surprise. In hindsight, we should have been expecting something like that - we just saw six statues come to life - but I suppose that it was too much like those classical adventure movies. As the door swung back, the markings again began to rearrange themselves on the face of the tablet. When it finally crashed against the side of the hall, ending the rumbling and revealing another long passage, the rumbling ended and the markings made an all too familiar shape.

"The Eye of Kietelen," I whispered, looking at the familiar picture.

Qumsal turned to face me, wide-eyed. "What do you know of the Eye of Kietelen?" She asked.

I shrugged. "Long story, it ties into a lot of what we're doing here and how we got mixed up in this mess in the first place. You'll meet him once we close the portal."

Looking at each other and nodding, Maddie and I approached the passageway, peering in. Qumsal looked after us incredulously before following us into the stone hall. Unlike the maze of tunnels and corridors we just came from, the walls here were lined with sconces holding little white balls of light, allowing us to see all the way to the end, where it opened up into... something. Too hard to tell from here. Qumsal let her little white wisp light (which had been following us the entire time) go out noticing the magic that kept this part of the temple in working condition. Whatever working condition was. Between the sconces, mosaics and carvings of T'Calu's worshipers decorated the passage, depicting humans in some very vulnerable positions laughing helplessly at the hands of various creatures. One that kept reappearing was a huge hulking beast, except its skin was more or less smooth across its entire body. It had arms and legs and torso, but I couldn't see any obvious head or features.

"Alright, careful for traps," I warned them, not wanting us to be delayed any longer. Blazing ahead into the tunnel, I kept a constant vigil against any funny looking blocks or sconces, but they all seemed genuine.

"This is just my own conclusion, young master," Qumsal said behind me, following close behind me and Maddie tagging along somewhat uncertainly, a little overwhelmed by the sudden power that this temple must have once had, "but I do not think we need to worry about any traps between here and the portal. The part of the temple I was assigned to protect was meant to defend the portal, and that chamber was the final test. Like the tablet, everything in this hall is meant to glorify T'Calu and her armies, ornamental purposes primarily. I may be wrong, but I suspect that we don't have to worry until we reach the portal."

"Alright then," I conceded. She made a pretty convincing argument. "But keep your guard up. If one of us falls into a trap, the other two should help as quickly as possible."

"The victim or the trap?" Qumsal asked, smiling. Rolling my eyes, I turned forward again and continued.

As Qumsal had suspected, we did not run into any traps through the tunnel. I kept looking the entire time though, I guess the first trap I fell into made me a tad paranoid. Qumsal just followed me the entire time, occasionally remarking on a particularly rare creature or a common tickling ritual that was enacted in ages past. Maddie spent the entire trip looking between the mosaics, observing the creatures and the positions of the followers. When she noticed the hulking creature I saw earlier, she looked more than a little intimidated. People seemed to cling to its skin, or at least were lying on it, and what expression that could be seen depicted mad hilarity. Maddie's shyness had returned somewhat, shuffling forward, trailing behind Qumsal and me.

What we stepped into was just like the circular chamber we came from times a hundred. A huge domed roof stretched from the base of the walls all the way up to a skylight looking up into the city itself, at least ten storeys above the floor. The room was twice as big as a football field, the sconces on the distant wall smaller than the width of my finger. Despite its size however, between the dozens of sconces and the light from the hole in the ceiling the room was plenty lit. No mosaics lined these walls, replaced by lines and lines, column and rows of the same scribbly text that was on the tablet. On the far side of the room was a colossal pair of rocky doors nearly half the height of the entire chamber.

A soft trickling sound echoed around the chamber, and upon a more thorough inspection I noticed a tiny stream-like decoration along the wall, the water moving from one end of the room to the other, creating the trickling. I was surprised to find water in a sand temple, but I suppose that even the priests and priestesses had to drink sometime, and it certainly added a nice calming effect to the room.

In the center of the floor, raised on a round platform of stone, sat a giant ring of rock that looked as if it could fit in three trucks side by side. Glowing white patches covered pieces of rock, and a gleaming yellow inscription in the same script as the tablet followed the curve of the ring. The platform was surrounded by a circle of torches, stuck straight p from the ground. Beside the ring of rock sat a short pedestal, with shining white lines reaching from it to the floor to the rocky ring. Hovering just inches above the surface of the pedestal was a small golden rock the size of a marble, rolling in mid-air and staying transfixed in the same point. From what I could guess, the little yellow rock was the talisman and the giant ring was the portal. I was just guessing though.

"The portal," Qumsal said, confirming my guess. She looked at it as if entranced. "I have never seen it for myself. It is remarkable."

"Yes, very impressive," Maddie said quickly, her eyes darting around the room, looking for something. "Now if we're done admiring the tool of the world's end, could we please just take the talisman and leave? I have a really bad feeling about this place."

"Really?" I asked curiously. "The rest of the temple didn't seem to bother you."

She shook her head vigorously. "I know, I know, it's just, something about this room, I'm getting a really bad feeling, like a vibe. Look, I know it sounds stupid, but could we please just grab it and go? At the very least it'll make me feel better. I just, agh, something about this place-"

"It's okay," I reassured her, putting a hand on her shoulder. "I'll get it and we'll leave. Can't imagine what's setting you off though."

"You really need to harden up, young girl," Qumsal said with just the slightest trace of disdain. "If this place is too much for you, then I doubt you will be able to stand up to T'Calu for very long, and if so your resistance is futile." I shot the sorceress a look, but she simply shrugged. Concerned for Maddie's sake, I began walking towards the pedestal.
11421112212211122121112211211.title: Last Stretch

114211122122111221211122112112.content:
At the time, I didn't notice what was happening as I was walking towards the pedestal. I was so wrapped up in my own thoughts and my guard was down. After having gotten this far, I foolishly thought this temple wouldn't have anything left to offer. I was wrong.

"Watch out!" Maddie cried.

I whipped my head around to face her, but saw more than I'd planned. Like the rest of the city, this chamber was covered unevenly with sand, huge clusters of it pooling in certain areas. Now it looked as if every grain of sand was now moving towards me slowly, hoping to avoid detection. Once they were caught however, a huge truckload of sand leaped off the ground and flew towards me like a giant arm or something. Sidestepping, I narrowly avoided getting swamped with the tiny rocks, the large swarm crashing into the ground and skittering across the floor. Then they started to regroup, but instead of launching at me again they slowly began to rise from the floor and take the shape of a person. As the figure became more distinct and developed, I saw that it began to take the shape of a woman, her hand over her mouth and shoulders shaking slightly.

Soon, her giggling resounded throughout the chamber. "Looks like I was found out," said a feminine voice. "It's a shame you dodged, you look very ticklish too." When her body was fully formed, she looked similar to Qumsal, except that her hair was parted and ran in two braids down her front and her skin was a shade or two darker. Sand still covered most of her body, only her arms sticking out of the mini-sandstorm the enveloped her.

"Who are you?" I asked, taking a step back and still trying to get over my shock. "More importantly, what are you?"

The sand-woman chuckled amusedly. "My name is not important, but know that I am the Sand Keeper, a protector of this temple and loyal vassal of T'Calu." She spat the last few words out in Qumsal's direction, who returned her glare. "I keep the portal's final guardian under control and direct him to our enemies."

"Qumsal," I called back, slowly backing away. "How come you never mentioned there was another guardian?"

"Because there isn't. I'm the Guardian of the temple, a role of which there is no greater honor," Qumsal answered, still looking right at the Keeper. "A Keeper is just a glorified pet owner."

"The title of Guardian only holds honor if you enact the duties of one," the Keeper quipped back. "Why have you betrayed our mistress? I've heard how you refer to this male in the chamber outside. Is the ticklishness of one youngling the price of your loyalty?"

"He is more than just another ticklish youngling," Qumsal replied. "His essences are unlike any I've seen before. You'd need to tickle him to understand."

The conversation at that point struck me as a little weird. Even weirder was when I realized that they were talking about me.

"T'Calu's return is inevitable," the Keeper said. "When the nightfire burns, the barrier between her realm and this one will weaken enough for the portals to pierce, creating the gateways for her armies to march through. Though I must wonder how you managed to arrive here so quickly, let alone discover the existence of these portals at all."

I was about to answer vaguely until Maddie reeled over and started groaning. Looking back, I saw Qumsal with her hand on Maddie's back, concerned for my friend's health. It looked as if she had just gotten hit in the gut with a sledgehammer. When Maddie finally began to uncurl, she stared uneasily at the big door behind the Keeper, clutching her stomach, looking like she was about to be sick.

"Be... Be..." she gasped, trying to force words between gritted teeth. "Be... Behind..."

"What is it Maddie?" I asked worriedly, rushing for my reeling friend. I slipped her arm around my shoulders, but already she was looking better. Enough color had returned to her face to make me think she would be okay.

"Behind the door," Maddie managed to say. "I got a... a really bad feeling about something behind the door, something big..."

"Oh," the Keeper exclaimed, raising her eyebrows. "It appears this one is in tune with our ethereal plane. The level at which she's aware is another matter however, my pet is rather hard to miss."

"You mean basically Maddie's spidey-senses are tingling?" I asked incredulously, knowing neither Qumsal nor the Keeper would know what that meant. It was supposed to be a joke, but to be honest, after all this weird magic stuff, I wouldn't be that surprised.

"That explains why this youngling seemed so uncomfortable before," Qumsal mused. "It was usual for inexperienced priestesses to have a negative physical reaction to a strong presence. Your friend is untrained and inexperienced with this ability, so it is little wonder she felt uneasy when she sensed the Keeper. And against what we are facing, it is no wonder she youngling feels sick."

A loud scraping sound was heard on the far side of the room, and I turned to see the giant stone double doors opening. Before them, the Keeper looked up into the slowly emerging shadow, gazing at whatever was inside. How she managed to cross the room so quickly I had no idea, maybe her sand powers or something.

"Um, Qumsal," I said, shaken, "what exactly did Maddie sense?"

"A beast of old," Qumsal answered, her voice infuriatingly calm. "I apologize, young master, I'm not aware of its origins nor am I even certain of what it is exactly. Though I have been told that it is a fearsome creature of great awe and admiration, one of many. The Keepers were to control these powerful beasts and direct them towards the enemies of T'Calu. When she was forced out of this world, each Keeper was assigned to protect their respective gate until her return."

"And as I was charged, so shall I serve," the Keeper responded, turning to face us once again. "Since nearly the dawn of civilization have I served our mistress, and so it shall remain until I am incapable of doing so. For millennia I have been the Sand Keeper, and as long as the last guardian of this portal remains I will continue to be a vassal as mighty as yourself, Guardian Qumsal."

Behind her, the giant double doors had opened slightly more, allowing traces of light to slide between the two giant stone slabs. Still, I could not see the formidable beast that Qumsal had mentioned very well. Neither had I heard anything else in the chamber beside the scraping of the stone doors; no roaring or growling or clawing or scratching, which led me to think of those comical moments where there's a huge build up for a giant monster in the movies and it turns out to be a little tiny thing you could step on. Then the irony would be that it's insanely strong. It was only a thought though, one clearly disproved as the doors finally opened wide enough for me to see inside.

As light from the hundreds of sconces streamed into whatever room was beyond the chamber, it illuminated the beast inside. Standing at least four storeys high, the monster towered over its Keeper and everything else in the room. Put basically, it was an immense headless giant with an abnormally large torso. It sounds comical, but looking at the creature's smooth featureless skin was quite frightening, especially when most of it was above my head level. And there were no features anywhere on this thing. How it saw, heard, or breathed I have no idea. But as it crashed its hulking form forward a couple steps, it was obvious that the beast was very much alive and aware.

"Behold, my ward and the final guardian of the portal, Golem," the Keeper introduced. "One of the Ancient Kings."

Maddie and I stared up at the thing in awe, but Qumsal didn't seem the least bit fazed by the arrival of Golem. Stepping forward, she addressed the Keeper directly. "What has T'Calu done to earn our loyalty?" Qumsal asked, doing my job in trying to convince our opponent to back down. "I am not a mere servant like you and Golem now are. This youngling has more power than you know, the power to go toe-to-toe with T'Calu. A wave of change is about to crash over the ethereal. Will you cling on to empty words and ancient promises, or take a stand in deciding your own destiny?"

"I am sorry Qumsal," the Keeper replied, and she seemed surprisingly genuine. "To me, honor and tradition still mean something, and there is still power in the ancient promises. I would rather stick with my old assurances than risk everything by turning against our mistress."

"So be it," Qumsal responded, her ring beginning to glow dimly. "It pains me that I cannot convince you otherwise. Young master, I will take care of Golem. You and your friend should focus on the Keeper." As her ring glowed more fiercely, sand began to spiral around Qumsal's feet, causing a bit of a breeze to rush past Maddie and me. To my surprise, the mini-sandstorm grew so fierce that Qumsal was lifted off the ground and carried very quickly towards the giant clay creature. When she got close, Golem seemed to become aware of her and began reaching for her and throwing ponderous punches. He moved slowly, but each time his fist struck the ground nearly the whole rooms shook, hinting at his pure strength. When I looked sideways at Maddie, she seemed equally dumbfounded.

While we were distracted, the sand behind us rose and took the shape of a body. "You should be more concerned with yourselves, younglings," said a voice from behind us. Both Maddie and I spun around to see the Keeper grin at us, a vortex of sand rising from the floor and racing towards...
114211122122111221211122112112.title: Final Guardian

1142111221221112212111221121121.content:
Before I could react, the billowing cloud of sand engulfed me completely. It swirled around me, each little grain feeling like a feather tip dancing across my bare skin. And there were plenty of grains. And lots of bare skin. Breaking straight out in laughter, I began stumbling around, trying to get out. However, it seemed wherever I went the sandstorm followed me, each grains of sand whipping across my skin so fast that they were off my skin almost as soon as they had touched it. They all left the tingling ticklish sensations though, staying long after they had made a pass. My underarms and feet were sheltered from the storm well enough, but the rest of me was terribly exposed. The sand tickled my sides and belly, breezing across my thighs and even brushing my buttocks. Thankfully my navel was also sheltered somewhat, though the sensations that surrounded it were tickly enough.

Gathering enough willpower to stop my useless attempts at protecting myself, I simply started running in whatever direction I happened to be facing. With this much sand, I didn't dare open my eyes. I shouldn't have even have risked breathing, but the sand seemed to avoid my mouth and lungs. The movement left my feet and underarms exposed occasionally, but I wagered that if I put all my effort into escaping I might be able to outrun the sandstorm. After a an excruciatingly ticklish minute, my gamble paid off and I burst into air that wasn't filled with sand zipping about. It wasn't long after that the residual sensations subsided, and I opened my eyes and saw that the vortex simply stopped moving once I had left it, the sand dropping straight to the ground. Satisfied that I wasn't in any immediate threat of being tickled, I looked to see how the girls were faring.

Qumsal was doing a good job battling Golem, at least as far as I could tell. Of course, with no face to any emotion it was hard to tell whether the clay colossus was being hurt by Qumsal's attacks or just becoming frustrated. The cloud of sand that held Qumsal off the floor was doing a good job of keeping her out of harm's way as she sent blast after blast of intense white light at Golem, presumably the form of 'pure' magic that she had tried to explain earlier. I don't know, I was still wrapping my head around these magical concepts anyway. Each hit exploded upon contact with the beast, eating away at the clay that made up his body, but more just filled the gaps left by the attacks. At least he didn't seem to be getting any smarter or faster, waving its finger-less hands around trying to swat Qumsal away, but it was apparent that one lucky shot or one wrong move on Qumsal's part and she would be hurled across the room. I hoped she was being careful.

Nearby, the sound of laughter drew my attention to Maddie and the Keeper's little duel, and it was clear the latter had the better hand. Four hands actually. From the pile of sand beneath Maddie's feet rose four arms made of the tiny grains. Two were as thick as tree trunks, holding Maddie's ankles to the ground in massive fists. The other two were human-sized, playing with her feet, exploring every patch of skin available. Unable to break the grip of her inanimate captor, Maddie could do nothing but thrash wildly on the ground and laugh helplessly as her the sandy fingers slid up and down her arches. "STAHAHAHAHAHAP PLEEEHEEHEEHEASE!" she screamed, banging her fists ineffectually on the ground.

"It appears you have inherited more than just your sixth sense from your lineage," the Keeper observed, smiling down on her plaything. She stood over Maddie, not looking particularly threatening or intimidating, just happily watching the young girl flail herself around in a vain attempt to escape. "I used to do this to the priestesses as well, keeping some of them here for days as their sisters performed the rituals honoring T'Calu. If our goddess was in a particularly good mood, she would take a priestess who was worthy into her realm to be tickled by her direct minions."

The only acknowledgment Maddie could afford the Keeper's story was a violent head shake as the sandy fingers continued to tickle her soles. Her laughter kicked up a notch when one hand wandered up to her toes, teasing the pads and underneath the stems. When it stuck its fingers between Maddie's toes, it had the fascinating ability to keep going no matter how small or large the space between was, any sand that couldn't fit just left outside the tiny crevice until the finger emerged. It meant that no matter how tightly Maddie scrunched her toes, a few grains of sand would always manage to slip through, brushing the tender skin within.

Enjoying the scene but desperate to win, I ran and tackled the Keeper, a move she had clearly not seen coming as she fell to the ground, startled. I knew that the best way to combat her would be to fight fire with fire, but as I eagerly dug my hands into her sides they scooped nothing but sand. Each time I tried to tickle her, her body just turned into sand like I was trying to dig into a beach. Looking up at the Keeper's face, I was met with a genuinely warm smile. "That was good work escaping my sandstorm, youngling," she congratulated. "Unfortunately for you, I am able to turn my body into sand at will, an ability that you appear to have noticed."

A prod in my own side made me squeal and roll off the Keeper, left exposed by her surprise attack. Another poke elicited another squeal, breaking down into giggles as the Keeper continued to prod my belly and ribs. Giggles quickly escalated into cackles as the prodding was replaced by ten fingers viciously worming into my tummy, provoking a stream of laughter from my lungs. I tried to crawl away, but the Keeper promptly straddled my waist and continued to tickle me, changing her tactic yet again. Now each finger traced random slashes and circles on my skin, soft teasing that didn't provoke as deep laughter as before but definitely more than just bubbly giggling. It was then that I decided that my navel was just too inviting as one of the Keeper's fingers dived into it and begin to swirl its nail around. It wasn't as long as Qumsal's, thank heavens for that, but it was still long enough to tickle like hell.

"You are as ticklish as Qumsal hinted you might be," the Keeper said. "I am still not convinced of joining you in your futile quest, but at least your sensitivity makes this fun as well as easy." As soon as she said that however, she was tackled - again - by Maddie and disappeared from sight for a moment. With her went the tickling, and after a brief moment I was able to get up and see that Maddie had fallen for the same trap I had.

"YOHOHOU'VE GOT TO BEHEHEHE KIHIHIDDING!" she screamed as her hips got a good working over, the Keeper's thumbs pressing firmly into her pelvis, massaging into the ticklish skin beside the bone.

As I got up, I noticed that Qumsal's duel had taken a turn for the worse. She continued whizzing around Golem, hurling blasts at his body with such focus that she didn't see the outstretched arm waiting for her. The collision didn't look as if it had much impact, but it was enough to knock Qumsal from her transportation, the miniature sandstorm dwindling down to the floor. However, instead of the sorceress falling to the ground, Qumsal found herself stuck to the clay arm. Golem seemed to be expecting this, and placed Qumsal on his enormous torso. Now she was stuck to the beast's body and unable to do anything.

Several arms protruded from Golem's body, human-sized and with all the fingers to be able to roll Qumsal onto her back and spread her limbs across Golem's torso. Now I realized what the mosaics in the entry hall were depicting. As Qumsal found herself spread-eagle, several of the clay arms began worming their fingers into her skin, tickling her through her thin white dress. For a moment Qumsal went bug-eyed, then she squeezed her eyes shut and began laughing as little clay fingers began burrowing into her sides, tracing shapes and fluttering in her underarms, pinching and squeezing her hips, and sliding up and down her arches. One set of hands were amusing themselves by playing with Qumsal's toes, teasing the pads and worming their way underneath them as well. It looked as if Qumsal was trying to buck and squirm a lot because her muscles kept straining against Golem's sticky body, but Golem must have been made out of some kind of adhesive clay because Qumsal never moved a centimetre, just laying there screaming with laughter.

With one of his three targets firmly stuck to himself and laughing helplessly, Golem began marching in my direction, apparently realizing that Maddie was more or less out of commission and that I was the only loose end. Things weren't looking up for the good guys.

I thought quickly, trying to figure out how to stop a giant creature made of clay from picking me up and doing with me as he pleases, when I noticed that Golem seemed to be avoiding the circular platform in the center of the room. It may have just been that he didn't want to accidentally crush the portal, but he was giving it surprisingly wide berth. Then I realized what he was probably avoiding - the ring of torches around the platform. They couldn't just be there by accident, meaning that they had some magical value or something. Whatever, it was my best shot at fending off Golem. I was kidding myself if I wanted to think that I could beat Golem with a torch, but maybe I could at least ward him off so I could help Maddie.

With no other option, I ran for one of the torches.
1142111221221112212111221121121.title: Round One

11421112212211122121112211211211.content:
With a mighty lunge, I managed to dive over to the ring of torches, barely dodging a grab from one of Golem's limbs. The behemoth stopped short from the fire of the torches and pulled back at a surprising speed. I grinned as I realised that I may have found a weakness of the creature and grabbed onto one of the torches, yanking at it as I tried to dislodge the thing and use it as a weapon. Rather surprisingly, it came away relatively easily from its holding spot and I held it in both my hands. The fire itself didn't feel particularly hot and as I waved it slowly from side to side, the flames seemed to leave a trail in the air.

Focusing on the matter at hand, I looked over to the Golem and saw Qumsal in an even worse position than before. Instead of hands, two squares had come out of Golem at her feet and shot out multiple tiny tentacles that assaulted every single inch of her feet without mercy. There were dozens of them coming out of the side of the square, pressing against the soles as they wriggled and writhed over the bare skin. They moved at astonishing speed to the extent where each of the small tentacles appeared to be a complete blur.

Qumsal's face shined with sweat as her bare feet were tormented without mercy, the clay hands tickling her sides, hips and underarms nothing compared to how her toes were tickled as the tentacles wiggled in between them and teased the digits relentlessly. The former servant of T'Calu screamed with laughter, her torment only added to as she was unable to move an inch in that strange clay mixture. Her eyes even glistened with tears and couldn't help but smirk a little as I realised that even she had limits. Getting back to the matter at hand, I moved forward towards Golem, bringing the torch up as it tried to lumber towards me, the flames flickering towards the construct.

It worked as Golem's body flinched backwards as I thrusted the torch towards it. It took a step backwards, quickly followed by others as it tried to get out of range of the fire. But as quick as it was, I proved to be that bit quicker as it stumbled backwards, the flame actually nearing it and brushing against its body. The clay the flames brushed against suddenly dried with amazing speed, cracking under the onslaught of the magical fire. The tickling on Qumsal suddenly stopped when that happened and the hands at her armpits vanished into Golem's body before I noticed the clay that had been cracked was now fresh and damp again. I grinned as I realised how to save Qumsal from her predicament and pushed the flame against Golem's leg, the clay once more drying up.
