More and more of the tickling appendages left Qumsal as Golem used the clay to patch up the parts of it that had been assaulted from the fire until Qumsal was left alone completely. That done, it took her only seconds to seemingly recover before pushing forward with her body with a yell and breaking from her bonds. Falling through the air, Qumsal stopped herself by calling up the sand to help her fly once more, sailing past me as she swiped the torch from out of my hands "Thank you young master!" She called out "I shall deal with Golem! But you still have to worry about the Keeper! Delay her while I subdue her beast!"

I thought that would be easier said then done when I turned to face the Keeper who was still working over Maddie, only with a bit more embarrassment thrown in for good measure. Sitting with her legs stretched out on the ground, the Keeper had place Maddie lying face down on her thighs and was holding her down with a hand on her back with one hand while the other was tickling Maddie's rear. Having long since gone scarlet from laughing so much, it seemed an extra hue had been added as the Guardian's fingers tickled the twitchy buttocks.

"NOOOTTHEHHEREEHHEE!!!" Maddie pleaded as she tried to push herself up only to be held down with remarkable ease "ANNYYYWHEHEEREEBUUTTHHEHEREEEEEAHAHAHAAA!!!" She cried out through her laughter, her ass only protected with a pair of flimsy panties that did little to prevent the Keeper's nails from wriggling over her ticklish cheeks.

"Oh, you say that now, but wait until I have tickled you everywhere." The Keeper said with a smile as her nails started giving light, ticklish pinches to both of Maddie's buttocks at random spots, only earning even more squeals and jumps from my ticklish friend "Then you'll be begging for me to tickle you here... and everywhere else in fact." She added with a satisfied smile.

As much as I was enjoying the sight before me, and the thought of what might follow, I needed to draw the Keeper away "Hey you!" I called out in a less than original way to do it "I beat your Golem, how about I get to have my turn at tickling you?!"

My shouts worked in catching the Keeper's attention and she stopped tickling Maddie, leaving her in a giggly mess on the ground as she turned into a floating cloud of sand "As you wish youngling." Her voice said in a confident tone "But do not expect me to be as easy prey as Qumsal was." With that, the cloud dived for me and without a better plan, I ran.

The places I could run to were limited however and with only a second to make up my mind, I went for...
11421112212211122121112211211211.title: Round Two

choices: The room was suddenly swathed in shadow.
114211122122111221211122112112112.content:
With the swiftness born of fear of being tickled half to death by a powerful sorceress, I ran as fast as I could towards the miniature stream that ran through the room. I had no real plan aside from hopefully keeping out of her reach until Qumsal had taken out Golem so she could hopefully turn her attention to the Keeper. The swirling cloud of sand proved to be fast and was soon close behind me as I reached the small stream, the water splashing around me as I ran through it. I looked behind me when I heard the Keeper cry out in alarm and saw that the water had splashed the bottom of the cloud of sand and a few brief flashes of light were coming from there.

After a few seconds, some of the sand vanished as a foot seemed to pop out of nowhere and landed on the ground. I was quite disconcerting to see as it was a foot of flesh and blood, the toes wriggling as it lay on the ground. It was cut off at the ankle with an odd cartoonish look to it as the top was simply round and without any marks to show damage on it. A thin golden chain anklet decorated the foot and twinkled in the light. 

The Keeper seemed to pause in horror as the foot came out of nowhere and I saw my opportunity. Turning around quickly, I ran for the foot and grabbed it, rolling over the ground as I tumbled a bit from my grab. The Keeper let out a scream of protest as I did this "Drop the foot now!" She ordered as the cloud hovered around, not coming closer to me as if in fear of what would happen. I looked at the foot itself with its rich brown skin, long toes and carefully cut nails. It was one of the prettiest feet I'd ever seen and as I held it, I realised it had some of the most softest skin I'd ever felt as well. I reached out and dragged a single finger down the long arch in defiance of the Keeper's order.

"NYYAHAHHHAANNOOSSTTAHAHHAAPPP!!!" The Keeper cried out the instant I started dragging my finger up along the foot and I started to realise that the water had splashed her in her sand form and had subsequently prevented her from using that power where it had touched her. I grinned in anticipation of revenge as I started to lightly drag my fingers up and down the sole, barely even tickling at all as I grazed my fingers up and down the foot. Even that light tickling had its effects however as the Keeper's shrieks got louder with each brush of the fingers I gave her.

"Call off Golem or I'll really get nasty!" I called out as my fingers softly brushed over her arch, the foot in my hand twitching about madly as it tried to escape but with no success. Looking over to Qumsal, I realised the threat wasn't needed as the sorceress had managed to largely contain Golem, having used the flame to dry the clay around its feet, keeping it stuck to the floor. Looking in the other direction, I saw Maddie slowly get to ger feet, bright red still from her laughter and embarrassment as she recovered from her ordeal.

"Well done young master." Qumsal said as she floated her way over to me, throwing the torch to one side. I smiled in response and continued my light teasing of the foot, dragging my fingers back and forth over the sole, causing increasingly loud shrieks of laughter from the Keeper as the sand cloud churned furiously "Time to bring you completely under control I feel," Qumsal announced. "Young master, if you drag her into the stream, she will be forced to condense and take solid form. Then she will be completely vulnerable."

Heeding Qumsal's advice, I waded a bit further into the watery dyke, bribing the Keeper's foot with me. Funnily enough, the rest of the sand cloud followed as if on a leash in spite of the Keeper's protests, and as I pulled the sand into the water via the foot (isn't that a weird sentence) it began to gather together and take shape and solidify. The sand that follows the foot into the water became a long and pretty leg, followed by the rest of a stunning torso until the Keeper was fully tangible.

The Keeper blinked as she took on a completely solid form, her eyes glistening with tears of laughter from her treatment and I had to admit she was a beauty. She looked like one of those beautiful women in a Bollywood movie with long legs, smooth skin and a toned belly. She was wearing what can only be described as a golden bikini with several small gold bracelets and anklets on her that served as a form of decoration.

I stopped tickling as the Keeper realised her situation and Maddie joined us, all three surrounding the unfortunate Keeper as she looked at all of us in turn, her foot still in my hand "N-Now wait just a moment..." She started.

"I don't think so." Qumsal interrupted "I think you've lost, and it's about time that we wrapped up here." The Keeper gulped nervously, watching as Qumsal summoned some hands from the sand...
114211122122111221211122112112112.title: Round Three

choices: She sent an array of tendrils after one of us.
Qumsal pushed back the darkness enough to distract T'Calu.
1142111221221112212111221121121122.content:
The torches were still burning, but regardless the room suddenly became dark even as they burned. Looking around, I saw the darkness flowing forward like a wave from the bead, the talisman, hovering above its pedestal. It seemed to be oozing the shadows, which warped around the room and wrapped it in a cold embrace. The walls became darker and harder to make out, the sand went that blackish-bluish color that happens at night, the torches appeared to dim drastically. All around everything just seemed a lot darker, and already it was putting me on edge.

Maddie seemed equally confused and startled, looking around frantically. Actually, she seemed even more unsettled than myself, her head turning rapidly and spinning around, her eyes wide with fear as she looked at the approaching and strengthening shadow. We were in a lighter area of the room, but we were still swathed in a light shadow that was growing darker, and Maddie looked with horror at the spreading wave. I wondered why, it's not like she knew what this meant - I certainly didn't - but then I remembered what the Keeper and Qumsal mentioned earlier, something about her having a sort of sixth sense or something. Maybe she was feeling something that was putting her off.

Whatever it was, Qumsal was feeling it too, that or she knew what the shadow meant. Her gaze was decidedly more confrontational, less afraid and more wary of the growing darkness. Her head was turning as well, though much slower than Maddie, less frantic and more cautious. The Keeper on the other hand seemed celebratory, a vengeful grin spreading across her face. "Yes, yes!" she cried. "Now you will all haHAHAHAHA!" She was getting annoying, so I cut her off by absentmindedly tracing my fingers up and down her sole, playing with her arch. I wasn't in the mood.

Though by far the most interesting reaction was Golem's the giant clay beast turning as if it were looking around with eyes it didn't have. Then, for some reason or other, it put a greater effort into getting out of his lock on the floor, pulling desperately at his dried up legs as he tried to turn and face the bead. As he was struggling, a deep and menacing laugh echoed around the room, seemingly from everywhere. "So nice to see you again Golem," a deep sultry voice that I recognized said, and the clay monster's efforts doubled. I had a feeling I knew who this was, and I also had a feeling that so did Golem.

"T'Calu?" I asked uncertainly, looking defiantly at the talisman.

From that direction I heard her rich sexy chuckle, and suddenly from the swirling shadows the great purple goddess stepped forward as if from some unseen door. She wore even less than when I saw her last time, completely bare and modesty only protected by shifting shadows tha covered her bosom and groin - and nothing else. "Perhaps I underestimated you, little one," she said somewhat condescendingly. "I had you figured for a brilliant general and harbinger of mine, but never did I expect you to be able to get this far. Of course, you had help." Those last words were pointed at Qumsal, whom she glared at as the sorceress began gathering sand around her arms.

"I have been more than patient with expecting my due," said the Guardian, the sand encasing her arms like a granular exoskeleton. "You promised me endless entertainment and joy, and instead I have been locked in here for millennia, guarding something that may or may not work. Besides, the sands are shifting and I feel a new power on the rise. Whether it is this youngling or something else I cannot say, but your time is ending T'Calu. This is just the start."

For a while, the goddess did nothing but glare at Qumsal. Then, after what seemed like whole minutes had passed, she grinned wickedly and thrust her hand out at the sorceress. At the same time, a wall of shadow rushed forward and slammed into the sorceress, dispelling the sand gathering around her and pushing her back against the wall. "Tell me then," she hummed, "is my power waning?" The darkness began encircling Qumsal, wrapping around her limbs and tightening, exposing her to the air as claws of shadow began growing from the wall behind her.

Suddenly, I was drawn out of my observations by a violent kick to the head, causing me to grunt and sending me staggering away. As soon as I let go of her foot, the Keeper dropped and scrambled over to T'Calu, groveling something fierce. I felt a slight surge of anger at her for kicking me, but it was an instinctive reaction that was replaced with detached curiosity at the Keeper's choice.

"Most powerful and benevolent mistress," she begged, her face more or less planted on the floor. "I fought for you until my last, until I could fight no more for your splendorous reign. Please, I beg of you, reward me with the betrayer's power so that I may better serve your glory.." So that was her plan, a grab for power. It made sense, though it still made my stomach turn the amount of butt-kissing she was doing just to get it.

Looking down at the nearly prone woman, T'Calu's attention was momentarily distracted from Qumsal, allowing the sorceress to regain some freedom of her limbs and postponing the punishment of the claws. "Yes you did, didn't you?" the goddess spoke, and the Keeper looked up with hopeful and ambitious eyes. "You also lost, allowing my pet to become ruined and falling to a simple youngling without a single vestige of my power. Pathetic."

The hopeful look in the Keeper's eyes immediately gave way to an intense terror as she crawled forward and nearly started kissing T'Calu's feet. "Please," she begged, "I did my best for you, I gave my all for you, everything for you, please do not punish me for the actions of a traitor. Please, let me continue serving you!" There were several degrees of desperation in her voice, though I could not imagine why she was so bent out of shape. "Everything that I am is yours!"

"Indeed it is," T'Calu said, lifting up the Keeper's chin. For a moment, the woman in the gold bikini looked hopeful again, smiling up at the goddess. Then, without warning, a pool of shadow opened up beneath the Keeper, and tendrils of darkness snapped up and coiled around her limbs, pulling her down like a sinkhole. The Keeper immediately began pleading and groveling, terrified and desperate, until her begs were replaced with insane laughter as the tips of the various tendrils began prodding her exposed skin. The ones wrapped firmly around her wrists pulled up her arms and reached down into her armpits, tracing circles in the exposed hollows. Those that were wrapped around her torso began prodding her ribs and sides, drawing patterns on her belly and poking her navel. Her legs were already swathed in shadow, and from her struggling hips I could tell they were getting hit hard. This continued for a long while, every inch of the Keeper pulled in made her laugh even harder as her struggles grew more and more furious. Eventually, after what felt like years of deafening laughter, her head disappeared beneath the shadow, which soon swallowed up her arms as well until there was no trace left of her.

Maddie and I looked at each other, fear rampant on our faces.

"Never really liked her," T'Calu stated dismissively. She reached down and wiped her hands off on the shadow surrounding her body, as if cleaning them from whatever muck her extensions had been covered in by the Keeper's actions. "She couldn't even train my pet properly. I'll bet he's dying to get another shot at me, aren't you boy?" The last question was directed, surprisingly, to Golem, who was still struggling to free himself from his cracked bindings that shackled him to the spot, a deep vibration reverberating throughout the room like a furious roar. There was obviously some history there, but right now we had some more pressing matters.

The whole time, I was inching away from Maddie, realizing that it wouldn't be long before she started targeting us. Once that happened, it'd be best if we weren't close together, so that we might distract and elude her if for only a bit longer. Maddie quickly caught on and began shifting as well, neither of us straying too far should we need to run in and tackle the goddess. Granted, I wasn't quite sure what we could do against her power, but I wasn't going to submit without trying.

Without moving a muscle, T'Calu spoke: "Don't think I've forgotten about you two."
1142111221221112212111221121121122.title: Intervention

choices: Maddie made it to the pedestal, yanking the bead from its position.
I finally found what Golem was trying to point me toward, freeing him.
11421112212211122121112211211211222.content:
T'Calu slowly turned to face me, smiling brightly but still somehow scaring me to death. With a dismissive gesture, she raised one of her hands and lifted a finger, which summoned a single tendril from the shadows that surrounded us. "I will have you, harbinger," she informed me. "Whether it's a voluntary service or not makes no difference to me, I merely need your untapped power and that precious body of yours to serve me." Straightening, the tendril curved downward and shot at me, speeding toward me faster than I could react...

Only for it and T'Calu to be his by a massive wall of sand, forcefully enough to dispel one and send the other flying. Despite the odd angle at which she was flying however, T'Calu still managed to land gracefully, her body seemingly righting itself so she could land on her feet within the darkness. Directly opposite her, Qumsal stood, a veritable sandstorm raging around her and filling almost as much space as the darkness.

"You are not weak," the sorceress said, her eyes glowing like in one of those campy action movies. "However, an even greater power is on the rise, and I intend to choose the winning side again."

T'Calu merely shook her head. "I should have expected no less from you." She raised her arms in a pose mirroring Qumsal's, and stands of the darkness around her flew forward and circled her, much like a hurricane. "You're always jabbering on about powers rising and falling, about how those who retain authority gradually lose it, blah blah. All this sand must have gotten into your skull and broke something."

"It is called entropy," Qumsal retorted, ignoring T'Calu's dig. "Everything in the universe is affected by it. Even you."

With their exchange over, both women flung their arms forward, forcing their respective elements toward the other. It shouldn't have worked like that, but the shadow and sand clashed directly between the two, both storms billowing uncontrollably.

Long before their fight even began however, Maddie and I were exchanging glances. Neither of us had a history of being psychic, but it was never too late to try. I was sort of half-hoping that Maddie's sixth sense could read my mind or something, but from our frantic gestures it didn't seem to. Still, through a mixture of pointing and waving, we managed to settle on a plan. Both of us nodded at each other, then ran off to get our jobs done.

Maddie's was a straightforward one; if she could, she was supposed to find a way to the bead and remove it from the pedestal. All the unnatural shadows in the room were billowing from the bead, or more accurately the pedestal just below it, and our thinking was that removing the bead might upset something and force T'Calu to retreat. Of course, that was all fine and dandy in theory, but in practice it appeared to be much harder than either of us had anticipated. As we both quickly found out, anything that touched the writhing darkness around the room quickly felt a gentle wave of tickles wash over it, not enough to be torturous but enough to get us to want to avoid falling into it. And since the pedestal seemed to be the source of it all, Maddie was basically supposed to fight a current in a rushing river heading upstream and avoid getting wet.

On the other hand, I was heading in almost the opposite direction, toward the giant form of Golem standing by one side of the room, near the wall beside his entrance. The shadows had begun to engulf the top of him because of his massive size, but the strange beast didn't seem the least bit affected by it. Perhaps expecting a creature made of clay to be ticklish was a bit of a leap.

To be honest, this part of the plan was a little half-baked, because neither I nor Maddie (at least, so far as I could tell from a bunch of frantic gestures) knew exactly what to do with Golem or how he was supposed to help. What we did know was that Golem, whatever he was, had no love for T'Calu and that the feeling was mutual. Our general thinking went along the lines of freeing him, so he could do something to occupy T'Calu further, and maybe along with Qumsal start turning the tide. The only obstacle: actually freeing him.

Behind me, the battle between the two godlike women raged on, but it was clear that T'Calu had the upper hand. As ubiquitous as sand was for Qumsal to manipulate, the pedestal provided T'Calu with a font of power for herself. It was also apparent that T'Calu was just that much stronger, because even while Qumsal's sandstorm was being overrun on either side the two storm-fronts were slowly edging toward Qumsal, who would routinely force the shadows back an inch or two with a massive burst, but not routinely enough to start winning.

The smile on T'Calu's face was obvious, and it looked as if she weren't even trying. "Surely you are not this weak, Guardian?" she asked, giggling. "It appears to me that the boy would have made it this far with or without your help."

Beyond them, Maddie was having a difficult time doing what she'd set out to. Simply getting to the pedestal was tricky enough and required a lot of coordination, since the constantly billowing shadows meant that the currents (or whatever shadows had) were fickle and continuously changing. The was no safe spot for Maddie to stand and rest on until she got closer to the pedestal, so one delay or misstep could begin a chain reaction that would end with her being swept into the darkness entirely. After that, who knew what would happen?

I myself had gotten to Golem fairly easily, but once there I had no idea what to do. His feet were still dry and locked up, heavy and unable to move. As big as Golem was, T'Calu was too far away for him to do any good. As I ran up to him, his entire being tilted downward, again as if he had eyes and were watching things unfold.

"Now, what am I supposed to do with you?" I asked rhetorically, not expecting an answer.

Responding to my voice, Golem turned and reached for the edge of the room with one hand, while reaching down toward me with the other. He was too big for me to simply step back and avoid him, and I thought for sure that he was just going to pick me up, plop me on him and start tickling me to death, but instead he just shepherded me in the direction he was pointing. Surprised that he was actually answering me, I once again wondered briefly what exactly Golem was that he understood human speech. The creature was insistent though, and so I hurried over to where he was pointing, toward the edge of the room and down slightly.

When I reached it, forging my way through clouds of darkness and breaking out in giggles whenever I stumbled into one, I looked around for what it was that Golem wanted me to find. I turned back to him, as if he could say something to guide me, but he just kept reaching for something toward the edge of the wall and near the ground. For a while I wondered just what he was gesturing toward, but I had my own answer before long as I took three more steps and splashed into the man-made river.

Of course! Golem was stuck because the magical torches had dried up enough of his clay that he needed to suck it away from his legs, locking them in place. If I could moisturize them again, then Golem would be free to move and fight! The only trouble was, Golem was too far from the river for me to just splash some water onto him, and I had nothing to carry it with.

Looking behind me, I saw something hopeful and something frightening. Close to the center of the room, Maddie was nearly at the pedestal. The billowing darkness was faster there, and she was often hit by a stray blast that send he reeling and laughing, clutching her sides or feet or whatever else had been hit, but she was making progress. She'd probably be at the pedestal in less than a minute, provided that Qumsal could hold out that long.

And that was the scary part. Over where the two magical beings were fighting, the shadows nearly entirely encompassed Qumsal's sandstorm, surrounding it like a container and slowly pushing in, strands of darkness already trying to reach through the billowing grains to get at the sorceress controlling them. The Guardian was trying her hardest to postpone the inevitable, but she was running out of juice and I could see her concentration slipping as some of the farther-reaching tendrils managed to sneak in a tickle on occasion, sending her into a fit of giggles. She wouldn't last much longer, and T'Calu still looked as if she weren't even trying. Noticing me looking, she smiled wickedly and waggled her fingers, as if to say "you're next" and send a shiver down my spine.
11421112212211122121112211211211222.title: Ants in a Storm

choices: Aftermath - the three of us regroup, now with a fourth member...
Rematch - now that the greatest threat is dealt with, Golem turns on us...
114211122122111221211122112112112222.content:
My heart sank when I saw Maddie take a bad step, placing a foot deep inside one of the dark currents flowing from the pedestal. I couldn't hear her, but I could see her squeal and yank her foot up, sending her off balancing and hopping right into another patch of shadow. Her cackles were lost in the screaming sandstorm and roaring darkness, but I could see her eyes squeeze shut and her shoulders shake with laughter. She continued dancing like that for a few seconds, lifting her feet to wipe away sensations that were already gone by the time it left the ground, before finally losing her balance and taking a tumble right in the middle of one of the many currents. Now I could hear her laughter faintly carried on the wind, as she went ballistic rolling about in the unnatural darkness, never actually going anywhere because it was not actually a river. Her feet kicked and her arms flailed, and it was clear she wouldn't be able to do anything now.

A roar-like vibration shook me out of my concentration, and I looked up to see Golem pointing more urgently. This time, his arm was angle slightly toward my left, or my right when I turned back to face the wall. The door he'd entered from was in that direction, but although it was open there was darkness - natural darkness - hiding everything I might have been able to see. Once T'Calu's shadows were gone the light would be able to illuminate the inside, but for right now I couldn't see a thing.

Still, when I looked back at Golem he seemed to be nodding enthusiastically, pointing in the same direction. So I took a few step forwards for a closer inspection, hoping to find something of use. It turns out I did.

Neither of the man-made rivers were still water, as that would have caused all kinds of nasty things to grow. So, since they had a current, the water had to be coming from somewhere. Beside Golem's door on either side were two large grates of delicately wrought metal with rivets shaped like flowers and teeth like leaves - or feathers. As I drew closer, as close as I dared to the darkness of Golem's habitat, I saw that on the wall between the door and the grates on either side were levers with wide bars. Equally intricate in design, they sprouted from plaques that seemed embellished with the shapes of waves, suggesting that it had something to do with the water system.

I rested a hand on the one nearest me, looking back to Golem to make sure I was getting it right. He nodded, furiously, but something caught my attention. It was Qumsal, who was nearly completely defeated by T'Calu's darkness. The sandstorm was a mere orb of activity about ten metres in diameter, barely enough to keep the shadows at bay from Qumsal, and even then some especially long tendrils frequently reached through it to tickle her sides to make her sway, or drag themselves across the tops of her toes to make her hop from foot to foot. T'Calu, who barely seemed to exert any effort this whole time, was now grinning devilishly, anticipating the break of the former Guardian of the Sands.

Without wasting another beat I pulled down on the lever. Then again, harder this time. The third time I leaned my entire weight on it, and I could hear the grinding noise of rusty gears clanking together as the lever descended slowly.

When it reached the bottom of its arc, I heard what sounded like wind. Well, the sound of billowing wind was already filling my ears, but this was different, thicker and heavier. T'Calu heard it too, and when she turned to look her tendrils abated slightly, leaving Qumsal alone for a bit. When Golem heard it, he almost clapped his hands as he turned to face the purple goddess. Then I realized what the sound was: it was the sound of rushing water, from behind the grate.

As if they were waiting for my realization, two floods of water burst forth from each grate and cascaded out onto the floor. The rivers promptly overflowed, spilling out into the main area as well. Within the span of five seconds the water level had risen to about my ankle - throughout the entire room mind you - and the water kept on coming. It rose to my shins, my knees, my thighs. A shiver ran through my body as the water rushed above my groin and hips, finally coming to a stop at about the height of my ribs. The cold was a stark contrast to the earlier warmth of the room, and I quickly submerged to lower my own body temperature.

Already the water was changing the dynamic of the room. While the darkness wasn't washed away by the water, it did seem to dissipate to the point where it didn't have nearly the same potency, and more importantly was no longer under T'Calu's control. Maddie sprung up to the surface over by the pedestal, gasping for breath but otherwise alright. Qumsal too was saved by the water, since she could refocus her efforts just on what was attacking her from above. From her - now cold - position of authority, T'Calu watched as the battlefield changed before her, but she could do nothing to stop it as she shivered much like I had. Apparently her immortal form wasn't completely devoid of all vulnerability.

But most importantly, it washed over Golem's legs, giving them much-needed moisture. Sure, he was so big that it effectively only reached the tops of his feet, but his body soaked it up fast and moved the water to the parts that needed it most. His legs grew back to their original size as if they were balloon animals, and though it was comical it was also a welcome relief. Too cold to stand, I half-swam back toward the action that was unfolding.

Which was unfolding fast. With two loud squelches, Golem's feet left the floor and squelched their way over to where T'Calu stood. The purple goddess now looked genuinely worried if not afraid, and sucked all the shadows she could from the room into a massive cloud around her. She even recalled her attack on Qumsal, who collapsed and received a much-needed break. All the unnatural darkness formed two banks of almost pitch blackness, from which T'Calu sent blast after blast at the approaching Golem, who was approaching fast, each one colliding into him full force but only serving to knock off bits of clay. There was nothing tickly or cheeky about her attacks now, each one was meant to outright destroy if they could, but for all her effort she may as well have been trying to move a boulder by huffing and puffing at it. Whatever Golem was made of, he had a lot of it and the water did the rest, as he just regrew whatever T'Calu blasted off.

In seconds Golem was on her, bringing his two massive arms down in a crushing blow that would have flattened any normal person. Before they connected however, T'Calu took what was left of her shadows and made two giant fists of her own, crossing them and blocking the attack. Both shadows and clay went flying, the former disappearing into nothing and the latter splashing into the water. Both regrew almost instantly what they had lost, and soon an exchange of blows occurred for what could have been forever.

Only, it just went until T'Calu's shadows didn't replenish themselves after every hit. The goddess noticed this as well, and when she looked to the source of her power in the room she saw an empty pedestal where the talisman used to be. A few meters away, Maddie stood huddled in the water, clutching the yellow bead-like object.

Realizing the she was fighting a losing battle, T'Calu spent all her remaining darkness in a massive burst that send Golem reeling and knocked off a good amount of his arm. If he had been human, it would have been grotesque, but as it was the creature just grew it back in a matter of moments. But by that time T'Calu was already on the raised dais, standing within the ring of rock above the water, wearing nothing but two scarves of shadow. The portal wasn't operational, but inside it was a small circle of darkness, enough for one to walk through.

However, when she turned, her looks was not one of frustration of anger, but one that was coquettish.

"Until next time," she bade, waving coyly before taking step backwards - and disappearing the next step as she entered the dark portal, which snapped shut and out of existence as soon as she was inside.
114211122122111221211122112112112222.title: Friends with the Monster

choices: A nest of bugs, flowing freely in the darkness.
A huge ring of rock - the portal
1142111221221112212111222.content:
The sound of scraping stone didn't stop the impromptu tickle fight at first, it was only as the statue pushed itself forward that the sound finally got the two off each other and staring into the next chamber "The young master chose well." Qumsal said breathlessly, shoving Maddie aside but not before hooking her nails into her top. With a rip, the material, battered and torn at during our adventures, came away from the sudden tug and Maddie squeaked as it fell to the ground.

Now clad only in her underwear, Maddie glared furiously at Qumsal as the sorceress smirked in response "If we are to waste time, at least let us do it so that the young master can enjoy watching it." She added with a grin, making me realise that keeping out of the way of these two didn't seem a viable long term option. At this rate, they'd be locked in a tickle duel to the death unless they calmed down.

"Can you two focus?" I snapped, gaining the attention of both of them "We've only got a limited amount of time before T'Calu breaks through to our reality and while I admit I'm enjoying the sight, this could really wait until later, OK? So just calm down, we're all working towards the same goal. No more snapping at each other, no more distrust, let's just do what we're here to do."

Both Maddie and Qumsal remained silent throughout my speech and when it was done, both looked slightly admonished although I could still feel the tension between them as they shared a nasty look. O...Kay, not the peace I was hoping for but at least they'd stopped arguing. The peace temporarily restored, I turned and walked into the room that had opened up to us, Maddie and Qumsal following close behind.

It was a huge, circular place, carved out of stone with the ceiling extending high above us. As we walked through the entrance way, I saw that the walls had twelve panels carved into them, each showed a beautiful woman in a pose and looking closely, there was something odd about them. Some held animal like characteristics, a Centaur for one or another was a Mermaid and even another one had the horns of a bull on top of her head.

I frowned in thought as I tried to piece the odd decorations together before Maddie suddenly gave out an exclamation "The Zodiac!" I looked towards her and she motioned towards the carvings with her hand "Each of these is a representation of a Zodiac sign. The Centuar is Sagittarius, the woman with the scales is Libra and so on."

"You are correct." Qumsal said as she stepped towards the middle of the room where an odd looking device stood. It was pole that came up to the average person's waist, carved out of black rock. A handle sat near the top, golden and shaped in the likeness of a spearhead, that could be pushed around the entire pole. It was then, as I was walking over to the pole and tripped over, I noticed there was a series of grooves in the floor that led from the pole directly to each of the carvings in the wall. Righting myself, I walked over to the pole and tugged on the handle, noticing that it could by pushed up or down to the top of the bottom of it and slot into the grooves.

"It's another puzzle, isn't it?" I asked Qumsal as Maddie and I investigated the room.

"Indeed young master." Qumsal replied "It would seem that these carvings could lead to another room or perhaps the talisman itself." Looking to the walls, she read the engravings above the carvings, most had been lost through the wears of time but she eventually spoke "The carvings tell us that the key to this room is to select the guardian to the door. Only one of these carvings is the true door while the others are decoys. We need to point the device in the right direction and fit it into the grooves towards the guardian. Whether it will take us to another puzzle or the talisman itself, I cannot say."

"And if we get is wrong?" Maddie asked, eyeing the carving that showed a woman with claws and feline eyes that represented Leo nervously.

"Then the decoy shall open and unleash a trap upon us, something that is bound to try and tickle us into submission." Qumsal answered with a bit more enjoyment in her voice than I liked.

"Could you tell us which one is the guardian?" I asked.

"Alas, I do not know young master. All I can offer you is a hint that is carved into the engravings 'Though I am bound to humanity, like hand to glove, never shall I feel, a person's love'."

The clue made us all stop and think. A rhyming couplet? Well at least it offered something. I frowned in thought as I tried to fit this to any of the Zodiac but came up short. What did love have to do with stars? Qumsal seemed equally stumped and none of us could think of an answer for some minutes until Maddie perked her head up "Virgo!"

"What's that?" I asked.

"Virgo is known as the Maiden in the Zodiac, never to feel a person's love? Maybe it's meant... um... you know..." Maddie blushed slightly in an adorable fashion as she tilted her head towards the pole.

"I see Virgo isn't the only maiden among us then." Qumsal said with a bit of nastiness, making Maddie flush a deeper red.

It seemed a bit of a stretch but it was better than nothing "Let's give it a go." I said as I grabbed onto the handle and started turning it towards Virgo "Although if this fails, you're going to be the one in the trap Maddie."

Maddie looked panicked for a moment before she noticed a grin that showed I was joking. I held the handle over the groove that pointed towards Virgo before taking a deep breath and pushing it down so that it slotted into place. A golden light shot forth from the tip of the handle and went directly to the carving. The light flooded the image until it shone as bright as the Sun and then vanished, leaving only a passageway before us.

"Well done young one." Qumsal said to Maddie "You were correct."

Maddie gave a bright smile and tried to hide her embarrassment somewhat with a smug grin "Well... You know... I only pointed out the obvious-EEEK!!"

"Don't get a big head now." I teased as I dug into Maddie's sides, tickling them as I wriggled my fingers into her bare torso. After a few tense moments like that, we needed someway to blow off the tension and Maddie had earned a bit of tickling for her attack on Qumsal. Qumsal herself needed no encouragement to join in the tickling, sneaking her hands up to Maddie's armpits and wriggling her long nails right in the centre of her hollows. Maddie's half-naked body bucked and writhed in between the two of us, caught between four hands that were busy tickling the life out of her. She jumped, giggled and squealed with each stroke and poke on her sensitive skin although this playful style of tickling didn't get her begging as it had done before.

"OK, enough." I said after a minute or so and Qumsal reluctantly stopped tickling as I did the same. Maddie continued to giggle after our hands left our skin and she leaned against me for support, her rear pressed against my manhood in a way that made me never want to move. Her face flushed, Maddie continued to softly giggle and smiled at the both of us, something that we returned.

"Now that we're friends again." I teased "Let's get on with our search." Qumsal and Maddie nodded as we looked towards the passageway that had opened and started to walk towards it. Beyond its opening, I could see...
1142111221221112212111222.title: Maiden's Challenge

choices: My cuffs seemed to fail, dropping me.
11421112212211122122.content:
"I'm sorry young master," Qumsal apologized, "but I crave the power that T'Calu has promised me, so her servant I remain." With that, another sudden wave of fatigue washed over me, and before I knew I had blacked out again.

-----------------------

A few moments of struggling told me I was no more free than last time I woke up. This time I was suspended in a square stone frame; my ankles and wrists were encased in glowing blue stone cuffs, every one of my limbs being pulled in the direction of each corner, stretching me out into an X. Surprisingly, I felt no strain on my wrists whatsoever, and chalked it up to the cuffs supporting my ankles well enough. Or maybe just more magic, I don't know.

Unlike before where darkness gathered in overwhelming groups in every corner, this room was well lit and surprisingly clean. Not a single grain of sand covered the blue floor, which was arranged in tiled rings around the middle of the room. Friezes decorated the curved wall, along with sparse mosaics of feathers and creatures and a woman that looked suspiciously like Qumsal. Small balls of shining white light floated over brazier-like protrusions in the domed ceiling, more than adequately illuminating the space. The fact that the ceiling was a dome suggested that this was the top room in the temple, meaning I had somehow made it to our objective in my sleep. On the far side of the room, opposite from where I was, a doorframe of stone lined the open space and the stairs which led down to the rest of the temple.

But what captured my attention was the object in the center of the room. From the floor rose a circular pedestal that reminded me of a well, about a meter in diameter and filled with sand. Hovering a foot above the sand was a glass ball, inside of which was smaller orb blacker than night. From it streamed inconsistent lines of ebony liquid; dripping from the bottom, pouring from the sides, overflowing from the top. It looked absolutely revolting, pooling in the bottom of the glass ball and then poured from a single point in the bottom of the ball and into the sand well below. Strangely, the sand was not blackened anywhere around where the vile liquid fell, as if the sand was soaking it up faster than it poured.

"That liquid is the physical form of the magical energies the Orb of Ethereal provides."

I turned my head swiftly to my right, and saw that Qumsal was also in the room with me. Her sharp grey eyes were focused on the oozing orb, as if it were the most beautiful thing she had ever seen. The effect the little thing had on the sorceress must've been mesmerizing, because her eyes became glassed over for a second before she pulled out of her reverie and focused on me.

"This is the object which you and your companion are trying to remove, thus depriving this city of its magic and denying the portal the necessary power. Those sands soak up the magical energy and channel it throughout the city - including the portal - acting as a conduit between the various magical apparatus in the city and the Orb. So you see, Guardian of the Sands has a literal meaning as well as symbolic. I've been charged with protecting those sands and the Orb, a duty I have performed for millennia. With the nightfire nearly upon us,T'Calu's return to this world is almost inevitable, and soon my duties will be complete."

"Why did you bring me here? The nightfire isn't for another three days, and you seemed to be enjoying me so much that I'm surprised I'm not locked in some tickle chamber or something."

With that, I earned a smile, as beautiful as it was the first time. "Believe me young master, I was very tempted to. Unfortunately, your companion is still somewhere in this temple, looking for either you or this orb. She'll never guess they're in the same place. Anyway I need to direct the majority of my attention to finding her - I can only scry locations in the temple, not people - but it would be much more convenient if more of the traps were operational."

Confused, I shrugged. "I still don't get it."

"Remember what I told you before young master? About mirth magic powering the magical tickling items in this city and in general? You fell into a non-magical trap, luckily in a place where I found you quickly, but there are so many more magical based ones. I was devoting myself to finding you two, and will continue to do so, but now that you're here..."

Realization dawned on me. "You're going to tickle torture me to power your traps," I stated. It wasn't a question.

A sly wink was given to me by my captor. "I might even jump in and do some of it personally for a while. This stone frame you're in is currently directing any mirth magic you create to the traps around the temple. Fortunately, there are a lot of traps, so you can be sure this will be very intense."

On her left hand, the turquoise in her gold ring began to glow, light shining from beneath the cracks made by the carved feather. Then her entire hand began to glow, then her other one. As they did, pale white copies of them emerged from the originals, flying around the air in front of her as another emerged, and so on. Pretty soon there were nine translucent left hands and nine translucent right hands all faintly glowing were filling the space around me. Only now did I notice what wickedly pointy nails Qumsal had...

"Now, young master, the feather may have been methodical and torturous, but you will learn that these will have a bit more life in them. Be sure to power all the traps." Another sly wink and she pulled up an image of a passageway somewhere in the temple, zooming through it like a camera on a rocket.

The ghostly hands flexed and quivered, as if excited to start with me. Quickly they flew around me, claiming parts of my body, even providing me with some entertainment as they swatted each other away from claimed areas. This didn't last long though as open spots were disappearing fast. They didn't all start at once, instead starting when each hand was confident that none of the others would challenge them.

Those at my feet were the first to start, a little isolated from the rest of me and therefore less challenged than the rest. Hands were doing a good job at keeping my arches squirming, sometimes scratching away and sometimes tracing shapes on the smooth surfaces. Another pair was having a good time worming between my toes and itching underneath them, causing them to flex madly in an attempt to block out the tickles. I'm sure they were lamenting the loss of some toe ties right then.

Next to start were the ones at my belly and ribs. Like my feet, four claimed this area and were busy exploiting it to its fullest. Nails explored every dip and crevice above my stomach, counting every rib and then going back to start all over again. My sides were being scratched and belly being drawn on with the ridiculously sharp points. A finger dipped into my navel, and, like last time when something was adventurous enough to go there, it was a peak in my already hysterical state. I swear that hand stayed there for minutes, and came back periodically just to watch my spontaneous explosive reaction whenever it dipped in.

Then a lot of other places popped in. Hands tracing circles that spiraled in towards that sweet spot in my hollows, starting from the edge and making their way in. Nails gently stroking my inner thigh, getting close to my genitals but never touching them, teasing the tender flesh. One pair, with nowhere else to go, scrabbled their fingers on the back of my knees, occasionally squeezing them too. A minor tickle, but it contributed.

Suddenly I was tickled in a place that few had ever done before. Just the barest tips of the fingernails made contact with my behind, lightly scratching away at my cheeks. The completely unexpected tickle sent my hips bucking forward to escape. However, the final pair of hands kneaded and squeezed my now completely exposed hips, sending them flying backwards into the spidery tickles on my butt, which sent me forward into the squeezes, and so on. From beyond my completely manic haze I caught a glimpse of Qumsal glancing my way, a smile spreading across her lips as she watched me dance forward and backwards within the confines of my restraints. To her - and to T'Calu, who I'm sure was watching as well - my dance was very amusing, a side show to go along with my torture.

Soon I lost all fight within me and resigned to just hang there limply and let the hands do their work. To be honest it was an enjoyable torture, and I knew that the chances of me escaping were almost zilch, but I struggled to pay attention to Qumsal's scrying, maybe distract her when Maddie appeared so she would be overlooked. I could not have predicted what happened next though.
11421112212211122122.title: So Close...

choices: Was intercepted by the ghost hands
114211122122111221221.content:
Perhaps the last thing that I expected, happened. Maddie crept through the doorway, and she somehow managed to avoid Qumsal's attention. You figured there had to be some type of magic that would alert Qumsal to Maddie's presence, but yet there she stood. Qumsal was in her own little world, scanning the various cameras in hopes of spotting Maddie. She would occasionally smile at hearing my frantic laughter, and luckily for Maddie, she wasn't in her line of sight. While the ghost hands worked over my helpless form, I made eye contact with Maddie, and tried my best to make her aware of the Orb of Ethereal, which was merely across the room from her. If she could dislodge it from its pedestal, we would be one step closer to preventing the return of T'Calu.

Maddie seemed to pick up on my signals, and she slowly made her way towards the Orb. Just as she started to get close, however, Qumsal seemed to develop a sixth sense and spun around quickly, spotting her. Maddie made a break for the Orb. Qumsal merely gasped and raised her palms towards my determined friend. Her hands glowed the same way they did when she summoned those tickling ghost hands (which were still going at me with great enthusiasm). She summoned a new pair, which traveled towards Maddie with great speed.

All I could do was giggle madly and watch as Maddie...
114211122122111221221.title: Maddie appeared in the doorway.

choices: "I suppose you might need my help..."
"Leave me here for T'Calu to punish"
1142111221221112212211.content:
You practically ignored the tickling as Maddie sprinted across the room towards the Orb. As the ghost hands closed in on your friend, she frantically pushed herself harder and harder to make it in time. With an impressive leap, Maddie collided with the Orb, clearing it from its pedestal. With a booming thud, the Orb smashed onto the floor, and the dark, magical liquid that T'Calu so desperately needed for her return was now covering the cold stone where Maddie lie.

The ghost hands that were tickling you faded away, and since the Orb no longer channeled energy to the frame holding you, you was released, now kneeling to regain your strength. Maddie was back on her feet, and she rushed over to help you up. You exchanged your feelings of relief that the other was okay, but you couldn't help notice that Qumsal stood motionless, her life's work, and honestly her sole purpose, crushed before her very eyes. Even as you made your way towards her, she just stared at the Orb, shattered and oozing all over the floor. She sank to her knees and sobbed. You and Maddie exchanged looks and actually felt kind of sorry for her. Luckily, you think you knew just a way to help ease her sorrow, if only for the time being.

Without saying a word, you wrapped the sobbing Qumsal into a hug and gently eased her onto her back. Maddie picked up on what you were doing and took hold of Qumsal's wrists while you straddled the girl's legs.

"It's time to stop with the tears, Qumsal," you demanded. Her tears stopped flowing, but she sounded hurt when she spoke.

"Why don't you just move on with your mission and leave me here to suffer! You got what you wanted; my beautiful Orb, gone! My life, destro-hehehehehehehed." You cut off her tantrum by squeezing her hips, earning a constant stream of giggles. You know that even though she was emotionally in pain, she loved every second of tickling she could get. You stepped it up by going at her belly. Even though you were only using two fingers, she writhed under you and let out wave after wave of frantic laughter. Eventually, you stopped to let her catch her breath and speak. "Thank you for trying to cheer me up, young master, but I am afraid that I won't be able to recover from such a failure," Qumsal sulked.

You tried to comfort her, "Who says this has to be your failure? If you join us, you can totally count this as a victory. Oh, and remember that offer I made you earlier? It still stands, but there's no way you can cash it in if you stay behind." Maddie gave you quite the confused look, but Qumsal certainly perked up a bit from hearing those words. Even though you had been tickled quite a bit today, being tickled by Qumsal without any of her magic was still something to look forward to.

Despite the tempting offer, she still looked deeply conflicted. She eventually made her decision.
1142111221221112212211.title: Managed to dislodge the Orb

choices: the high ground to the right
11421112212211122122111.content:
Qumsal let out a defeated sigh. "I suppose you'll need my help for what is to come." I was happy to hear that Qumsal was going to tag along, despite Maddie shooting me looks of disapproval. Bringing Qumsal was dangerous, as she could turn on us at any moment. However, her connection to T'Calu intertwined with mine, and I felt there was no way we could leave her behind. Besides, being tickled by Qumsal wasn't by any means a negative outcome, should I end up in that position. If only Maddie and Qumsal could learn to cooperate, it would really put my mind in a better place.

         The Eye of Kietelen, seemingly out of nowhere, appeared where the Orb had been positioned. A bright ripple of space-time manifested itself a few feet from the Eye, a portal to the underwater civilization where our next foe lie in wait. The Eye sensed how concerned I was with moving forward. "You are right to worry. I sense that the Guardian of the Seas, Tymeira I believe, will be extremely prepared for your arrival.

"What makes you say that," I questioned.

         "There is no doubt that Tymeira felt the destruction of the Orb. Upon shattering, the potent magical energy within the Orb was released quite rapidly. A surge of magical energy that powerful would be sensed in any of T'Calu's devotees, regardless of which realm they may be present. Point being, the element of surprise you enjoyed with Qumsal will not be a luxury in your next endeavor."

         "Hey, at least we have an extra troop this time around, there's no way she expects that." I announced while giving Qumsal a poke. I continued my efforts to cheer her up, and I think I was starting to get to her. She let out a less than satisfied giggle and lazily brushed my hand away.

"Young master, I must warn you," Qumsal spoke up. "I was rather disciplined in my approach to capture and torment you, but I fear that Tymeira has much more magic to work with. Not to mention she is probably aware that we are coming. There will be many more magical traps to avoid, and it might prove difficult, perhaps even impossible, to avoid detection."

         "And I'm sure you were thinking my escape was impossible when your feathers and ghost hands were going at me earlier, but here we are." I remained as headstrong as ever. Before we could continue our back and forth, the Eye interjected.

         "Enough. I must return to T'Calu's realm. Step into the portal, and once again, good luck on your journey."

         Making haste, the three of us stepped into the void, and one by one we appeared in a dark, musty cavern. Thankfully, there was enough light present for us to group up and observe our surroundings. The source of the faint light was rather high up on what appeared to be the cavern's equivalent of a ceiling. Glowing plants, resembling a type of moss, had grown in clusters, and emitted shades of green, blue, and yellow streaks of light. As my eyes adjusted, I took note of the surfaces around us, and was surprised to see the stone floor, albeit not level, was smooth. There were no pebbles or rocks anywhere to be seen, and my bare feet appreciated such an accommodating surface. I was finally able to make out structures in the distance. Several large buildings stood in a row, as if they were carved out of the cavern itself. One seemed to tower over the rest, and I decided that would be a great place to start our search.

         Getting there might prove tougher than the search itself. There were three possible pathways that lead to the structure. The most direct route would be a tunnel that offers a straight shot to the stone city, but there's no telling what could be waiting at the other end, or even inside. To the left, a rather large pool of water had formed at a lower elevation, just below the tunnel. I'm not sure how a lake can form under an ocean, but that's hardly relevant. Crossing would require us to swim, which could prove quite noisy if we aren't careful. Lastly, to the right of the tunnel, a series of jagged rocks had compounded over time, forming a bridge of stone that overlooked the entire area. Taking this route would offer us the most information about our surroundings, but we would be the most exposed should anybody be watching.

         Maddie and Qumsal hadn't broken their silence, and they patiently waited for me to make up my mind on which route to take. Eventually I chose...
11421112212211122122111.title: One Guardian Down

choices: You make it halfway before something grips your ankle
You and your friends swim across no problem
114211122122111221221111.content:
"I think we should try to swim across," you spoke up. "We likely won't be spotted so long as we keep quiet."

Qumsal stood there contemplating the thought when Maddie spoke up. "I don't really think getting drenched is the way to go, but if you think it's the best way to not get caught, I'll get over it," she smiled at you. You didn't quite consider the fact that the girls might not be so comfortable with the swim. It was an easy thought to have though, as you've been naked since your initial capture at Qumsal's hands.

Speaking of Qumsal, the dark haired beauty finally interjected. "I've heard tales of a creature that guards these premises, we should be extremely cautious from this point on. Young Master, I'm not sure if swimming this lake would be good or bad for us, truthfully." Maddie's eyes lit up like they usually do when she has a good idea. Remembering the Book, Maddie quickly cracks it open and begins flipping through page after page.

"There's no mention of any creature here," Maddie states. "There's only mention of Tymeira, Guardian of the Seas, and her loyal pet." Maybe her pet is this fabled creature. It would make sense, but the vague description gives you little to go on.

"Well, whatever this creature might be, we're likely to face it at some point no matter what," you said. "My gut is telling me that swimming is our best bet, and time is always working against us, so we better get moving."

You made the executive decision to go for the swim. The water was quite warm and surprisingly clear. There were absolutely zero pollutants, and as you ventured further across the lake, it got considerably deeper. Maddie and Qumsal quickly followed suit, but their clothing slowed them down slightly.

What happens next?
114211122122111221221111.title: A dangerous crossing

1142111221221112212211111.content:
Treading water, you turned to check the progress of your friends. Maddie was a mere 10 feet away, but Qumsal had fallen behind. Swimming in a dress turned out to be somewhat difficult for the young sorceress. Maddie's sweater, despite being soaked and thus much heavier, didn't seem to give her many problems. Maddie's screeching voice pierced your thoughts and snapped you out of your trance.

"Look out!" she shrieked as a black tendril gripped your left ankle. You tried to kick your foot free, but the tendril, as black as night, merely tightened and held your foot in place. Maddie tried to swim towards you to help, but she wasn't fast enough! A second, slippery tendril found your right wrist, and a third gripped behind the base of your neck. Before you could even react, you were pulled underwater at surprising speed. Thankfully, you managed not to swallow a bunch of water, as it would've been a shame to drown during this great adventure!

You tried to twist and turn, but the creature had remarkable control over your limbs. Even though it was hard to tell with all the thrashing, it didn't seem like it was pulling you downwards, but guiding you with a natural current, somewhere. The panic would come to an end after about 35 seconds, as the beast, with one powerful movement, hoisted you in the air of a new cavern. Precious air filled your lungs as the beast held you in place, giving you a view of your new setting. Where the cavern in which you began your swim was rather dim, this new cavern was extremely well lit. Bright orbs of pure white lit the space in its entirety, revealing a massive cavern made mostly of water. Several rocks formed convenient islands, five in total, that could support a person or two each. You started to worry about your friends when suddenly, more tendrils shot out from the water below. You let out a sigh of relief when your friends' gasps for air could be heard behind you. A subtle feeling of guilt washed over you, as you led them to be captured alongside you, but you found some satisfaction that they were at least unharmed.

Your thoughts were interrupted as the tendrils spun you around, giving you a view of your friends. You shared the same predicament with each of them, one tendril supported each of your limbs. Getting a better look at them, some were rather thin and slippery looking, while others looked more like tentacles. Tentacles with purple undertones and greater thickness probed around Maddie's sweater, earning a few giggles as they found a home in her armpits. Qumsal's laughter soon followed once a few slippery tendrils started fiddling with her tiny feet. To your surprise, you remained untouched, simply hanging there as the warm air caressed your nude form. Your peace didn't last very long, however, as you spotted several figures coming your way.

Your heart rate picked up considerably at the sight of seven women approaching. The way they were approaching was most interesting. Six of them traveled via massive wings on their backs sporting vibrant colors. Every shade on the spectrum was covered, from bright yellows and oranges to deep purples and calming blues. The women were very beautiful as well, and they all shared the same tone of ashen grey skin. You gulped hard as you realized these women were likely from T'Calu's realm. You took a closer look at the seventh woman.

A woman who looked considerably more human from the others was being carried by the same kind of tendrils that still held your giggling friends in the air. She was rather cute and had fiery red hair that fell to the middle of her back. While her six companions were barely clothed, she wore a fitting magenta wet-suit that accentuated her curves rather well. No doubt this was Tymeira making her grand appearance. Your friends continued to giggle and laugh obliviously as the beauties were finally near.

"My, my, what ticklish intruders we have!" Tymeira exclaimed. "Ladies, why don't you welcome them while I chat with our third guest here." Tymeira eyed you and licked her lips as your friends were hauled a bit further away. Three of the flying women claimed Maddie and the others made their way to Qumsal. Maddie's soaking sweater was peeled away from her and discarded to the waters below. Her ribs and armpits were relentlessly kneaded and squeezed by two of the ashen women while the third played with the sweet spot on her hips. Qumsal didn't fare much better; each foot had its own tormentor while a raven-haired woman expertly raspberried her sides and belly.

It took Tymeira's right hand to guide your vision away from the sight of your friends being tickled. She pulled your chin towards her and locked eyes with you. "Let them have their fun while we talk, unless you'd like to join them?" Tymeira questioned. "My pet and I could show you quite the fun time."

"What is there to really talk about?" You responded. "Aren't you just going to trade me to T'Calu the first chance you get?"

"Who knew that a Chosen's spirit could be broken so easily." Tymeira started poking and pinching around your belly. "Maybe I was wrong to bring you here." Tymeira stated teasingly. You probably had a confused look plastered all over your face despite your giggles. You had no idea what she meant by Chosen, but maybe there's hope for a bargain after all.

"Whahahat does Chosen mean," you said.

"The Chosen is a person of prophecy, destined to overthrow the corrupted Bringer of Laughing Torment and Delight, T'Calu." Tymeira explained. "It is said that the Chosen has a strong connection to these realms and to tickling in general." She sped her fingers up and explored more of you, forcing more laughter from your lips. "So, convince me that you're indeed the Chosen, make me an offer that only a Chosen would make." Despite the ticklish distraction, the words practically leaped out of you. You made the same offer to Tymeira that you made to Qumsal not too long ago.

"If you hehehelp me, you can tickle mehehehe whenever you wahahant." Tymeira stopped her ticklish assault on your tummy and was seriously considering the offer.

"You know what, I think I need some time to think it over." Tymeira deviously grinned. As if she could communicate with her pet, the tendrils holding you started to react. They laid you out horizontally while several more participated in supporting your weight from underneath you. Slippery tendrils slithered over your torso, covering your skin in a slimy liquid from the depths of your armpits to the crevices between your toes. Even such mild action was rather tickly, and you found yourself giggling madly as the tendrils lathered up every inch of you, including your more private areas. The tickling progressed as two tendrils began stroking your feet with consistency, occasionally worming between your toes for added effect. Your armpits each received a probing tendril, sliding around searching for the sweet spot in the center. Several others swirled around your rib-cage and sides, while a lone tentacle strategically placed its suction cup over your belly button, mimicking the effects of repeated raspberries. Your laughter was frantic and unrelenting by this point. Tymeira smiled as you wiggled around in your inescapable bonds. Eventually, the tickling stopped and your laughter died down.

"Well, I've made my decision." Tymeira stated.
1142111221221112212211111.title: Another proposition

choices: The girls decide they want to tickle you
Tymeira decides to hold you to your agreement
11421112212211122122111111.content:
"Very well, I accept your offer," Tymeira stated. "And should I be right about you, I expect you to honor your end of the bargain."

Still panting from the tickling, you reply, "what do you mean if you're right about me?"

"Well, I stated earlier that I think you're the Chosen, but to be completely honest I'm not one-hundred percent sure. The Chosen is said to have a strong connection to these realms, and it has been foretold that the Chosen would one day usurp control over the realms and restore order and purpose among the various factions that exist here."

Your head was spinning from all this new information. "Wait, so, you mean to tell me that I might be T'Calu's replacement? I'm supposed to steal her power and become the new Bringer of Laughing Torment and Delight?"

"Well, essentially yes," Tymeria assured, "but you would be free to forge your own path. You see, T'Calu wasn't always so determined to conquer your world. There was a time when she was rather laid back and dare I say caring. Over time though, the power slowly took over her and transformed her very being. Now, she only uses tickling as a weapon, and nobody has the courage nor the means to stand up to her, until now."

"What makes you think I could possibly stop her?" You say. "I'm only here to prevent T'Calu from conquering my world and enslaving me forever!"

"Is it really so hard to believe though?" Tymeira questioned. "The Chosen is said to have a strong connection to these realms, and I definitely believe that to be the case. Qumsal wouldn't have followed you if she didn't believe the exact same thing. The Chosen loves all aspects of tickling. Tickling others. Being tickled himself." Tymeira forced a laugh by pinching your ribs a few times. "But most importantly, his intentions are pure, and you've already proven that by standing your ground with T'Calu in the first place. Any normal boy would've accepted her offer, but not you. You saw past the immediate pleasures she offered you and thought of not only your future, but everybody else's as well."

She made some good points, and this really was your best chance at stopping T'Calu's return anyways. "Okay I see your point, thanks for your help." You smiled at Tymeira. "Now can you let me down please?" She smiled back at you before a few parting tickles were bestowed upon you. She lowered you to a smooth rock platform below, but she remained suspended in the air. You forgot that during your entire conversation, Maddie and Qumsal were being tickled relentlessly by the ashen beauties from T'Calu's realm. Tymeira turned to face them. They were so focused on tickling your friends senseless that they didn't notice you being let down.

Before they could react, the ashen women were ambushed by a flurry of new tendrils, gripping their wrists, ankles, around their waists, etc. They flapped their vibrant wings in complete panic, but it was too late. Each woman was unable to escape, tendrils slithered all over their exposed flesh, earning belly laughs and giggles. Meanwhile, your friends were being lowered to the same platform as you. They were exhausted, and several spots on their bodies were bright red from all the tickling. They looked at you in confusion, but seemed to understand that you once again managed to pull off the impossible. They looked behind them to see their former tormentors getting their just desserts.

While your friends catch their breath, you decide what to do next.
11421112212211122122111111.title: Tymeira Agreed

114211122122111221221111113.content:
With T'Calu's minions handled, Tymeira made her way back to you and your friends. "Sorry about that ladies," Tymeira apologized, "I had to be sure your friend here was the right man for the job." Maddie and Qumsal seemed confused, but ultimately knew what she meant. "Now, if you'll excuse us, I think I'd like to cash in on our little agreement." Tymeira eyed you hungrily.

Shocked, you responded, "Really? Right now, you can't be serious? We don't have time for this." Maddie and Qumsal merely observed the exchange, saying nothing.

"Oh I think we have PLENTY of time for this. After all, I'm risking an eternity of tickle torment on the off chance we're able to defeat T'Calu and her minions," Tymeira quipped back. "I'm gonna find every last tickle spot on you before we proceed, and there's nothing you can do about it."

You shivered at her words. Despite wanting to get moving on the whole T'Calu thing, part of you was thrilled that Tymeira was about to take control over you. Qumsal and Maddie both giggled. "Tymeira," Qumsal spoke, "would you perhaps allow Maddie and I spectate this ordeal? I think we would greatly benefit from learning these tickle spots as well?"

Tymeira simply smiled. "Of course, I might even let you two join the fun, let's see what happens." Tymeira helps you to your feet. "How about we go somewhere more private?"

Tymeira takes you to...
114211122122111221221111113.title: Tymeira decides to hold you to your agreement

choices: grabbed a tool from one of the racks
1142111221221112212212.content:
My laughter ceased as the hands that were toying with me made their way over to my friend. Maddie's ankles had been seized only a few feet from where the Orb of Ethereal floated on its pedestal. They dragged her away from the Orb when the other hands showed up to help out. They took control of her wrists and managed to flip her onto her back. The remaining hands did what they do best and began tickling her. Her sweet laughter filled my ears as the hands worked their way underneath her sweater, tormenting every tickle spot they could find.

Qumsal let out a huge sigh of relief and made her way towards me. "Well, young master, that was a close one. Your friend has proven quite resourceful; she managed to avoid being detected by my eyes in the sky. Quite impressive, really."

"Is there a point you're trying to make here," I said with a hint of animosity, "or are you just trying to rub it in my face?"

Qumsal merely smirked, took a step closer, and started tickling your right side. "Well, young master, I was going to give you the chance to reward her efforts personally, but now I think I have a better idea." I could see the sorceress thinking. It was a far cry from her original demand, but it was a step in the right direction. Eventually, she replied, "I agree to your terms. I'll help you if you let me talk to the Eye of Kietelen."

Standing up, I offered my hand to both shake and help her up. "So, we have a deal?" Without saying anything else, Qumsal nodded and took the offered hand, pulling herself up until she was right beside me. "So what do I do to the orb?"

"Simply removing it will deny the portal of the power necessary to open," Qumsal told me, taking my offered hand and pulling herself up next to me. "However, the base energies that it provides will pool without the sands and magical apparatus to use it, and eventually it'll flood the city with raw energy. That's a bad thing before you ask, too much base energy without a purpose tends to be unstable and could cause a catastrophic disaster."

"Then we destroy it?" I asked, moving in closer to examine the glass ball and the black orb inside.

"Impossible. There is no way to destroy the Orb, and all attempts have failed miserably. You'd have better luck reaching the center of a star - there's more energy in the tiny orb than the combined power of every star in the Milky Way galaxy."

I thought for a moment, trying to come up with a solution for this seemingly impossible task. "You said that the energies this Orb creates will not disappear unless used in magical equipment. So if we found another item that uses these energies, then we could move the Orb to that and both use the energies to do one thing while depriving the portal of them."

"That could work," Qumsal said thoughtfully. "There's a backup magical lighting system with a finite source of energy, designed to kick in if the main lighting fails for whatever reason. It's separate from the main magical system, so moving the orb there would keep the lights on but deprive nearly everything else of the energies. The receptor is in the bottom of the temple, not far where you fell into that trap actually. We'll bring the Orb there, and I'll reconfigure the backup system to take it."

"I have a solution," she told me. Waving her left hand around in the air, I saw faint green lines shimmer around it, slowing gathering together and forming a shape. Her hand stopped moving, and when she put her thumb and forefinger together a green feather appeared between them, held by her pointy nails. "This is another mirth magic tool, though its purpose is a bit mundane. It will hover around you, a short distance from your body, until you snap your fingers. Her body was a silhouette from within the dark green gelatin, occasionally thrashing, but slowing down from exhaustion. I shuddered to think of what torment it must be, being encased and tickled from all sides constantly!

Taking my eyes off of the creature, I saw one of the larger exits of the room. It seemed to be important because of the various murals that circled the threshold. Clutching the book tightly, I glanced back at my trapped friend one last time before venturing deep into the Water Palace.

And just my luck, the blob was now somehow climbing the cavernous walls! It must have been like glue, as its bottom surface was inching up the curving cave surface. It seemed to be heading for a large cravesse in the wall... I gulped, hoping that I would be able to find it again. Maddie's body dangled from within the ooze, limp but still emitting a quiet giggle.

"Sit tight, Maddie," I muttered to myself, dashing down the exit and deeper into the complex.
1142111221221212.title: Deeper into the Sea
